Nor Phoebus (when unto his gold-ſtrung Lyre
He for ſuperiority did ſing
His ſweeteſt Anthems and beſt Madrigals
Againſt ambitious Pan) made harmony
To parallel the ſweetneſs of your tongue.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: If that all my endevours can deſerve
At this height your affection, by my fault
It never ſhall decreaſe.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You over-act me much, but never ſhall
Have thoughts beyond me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I pray you ſpare my company a while;
A while I would be private with my woman.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Lady, I will do things unwillingly
At your command: but give me leiſure (faireſt)
To print my heart upon your heavenly lips,
Ere my departure hence—The Ottoman Emperours
In their immenſe Seraglio never ſaw
Your matchleſs features in their numberleſs
Succeſſive multitudes. I am ſo bleſt,
That my exceſſive joyes cannot be gueſt.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nentis!

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Unfold thy heart unto me: Let me know
What thoughts thou haſt of me.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: I may offend.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Indeed thou ſhalt not.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: Then I do wonder (Madam) that you will
Beſtow your ſelf (I think) unworthily.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: This is unpleaſing to you, I will be
Hereafter ſilent: I have offended you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No: proceed.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: You are a Lady untill now unſtain'd
With any blot (ſave obſtinacy to
The brave deceas'd Carionil) and will you
Give the world reaſon, a good one (pardon
My honeſt boldneſs (Madam) to taxe your judgement;
And (which is worſe) your virtue for this choice?
Is not Falorus far more worthy of you?
Marry him (Madam) and live ſtill in England.
I'me ſure my counſel would be ſeconded
By all the friends you have, did they but know
As much as I. But (Madam) if you have
Settled your affection paſt recall, and are
Reſolved, I will be moſt obedient
And ſecret unto all your purpoſes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And wilt thou go to Aethiopia with me?

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: If I do get no Servant before, and if
You will (if I diſlike the country) give
Me liberty to return home.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Moſt willingly.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: My Lord Falorus.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Phyg.
sp.l: If I can find the leaſt opportunity
I will try (Nentis) of what mettal th'art made.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I hope (Miſtris) our company
Is not unwelcome to you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: By no means Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: How gently it paſt her tongue!
For that ſweet word I kiſs your hand, dear Lady.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Where did you leave my father my Lord?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Above a reading Guicciardin.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: Sir, I can perceive when I am flatter'd.

sp.speaker: Phyg.
sp.p: Earneſt expreſſions of love deſerve a better name.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: Why Sir, I cannot believe you love me.

sp.speaker: Phyg.
sp.l: You need not doubt of that, Miſtris, I do
With as much fervency as ſervant can;
I do beſeech you Lady to believe me.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.p: They are of eaſie faiths that believe all their ſervants ſay.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What ail you my Lord? you are not well.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Unwelcome gueſt away—I was thinking of—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I ha forgot—would they would all love me—
I am moſt ſtrangely alter'd on the ſudden:
My friendſhip (I fear) will be too weak a tye
To make me ſilent.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Thou hadſt a Maſter did deſerve thee better.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: But he is dead, and I am yours by his
Laſt Legacy.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: What wouldſt thou ſay?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I hope y'are well.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: He has found out an alteration in me:
I muſt beware of publick ſigns. I was Privately▪
Full of Carionil; my thoughts were buſie
Concerning him:
Madam, I pray you pardon my neglect
Of frequents viſits; I have been too guilty.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You have not offended.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Tis your great goodneſs to ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: This, Sir, is too importunate.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: To ſlack (dear Miſtris) but wink at my inſufficiency.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: You ſaid, you love no woman in the world
But me.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: And may you hate me if I do.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.p: As I ſee you ready to give me full ſatisfaction that you mean faithfully, ſo ſhall you find me willing to requite you.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: No man can boaſt ſuch happineſs.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.p: Sir, be moderate; y'are not ſo ſure of me, but (upon occaſion) I can retire; neither would I have the company take notice of us.

sp.speaker: Phyg.
sp.l: You ſhall command me (Miſtris)

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Theſe paſſions are new to me: woo'd I were private.
I never did obſerve her ſo well before.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: What ſay you (Madam?)

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You ſaw not my brother Philander to day?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: No truly Lady I did not.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Your brother (Nentis ſaies) ſhall ſhortly be married to
The rich widow her ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: So he doth hope.

sp.speaker: Roſin.
sp.l: Madam, dinner ſtayes of you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You hear my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nay Anclethe, ſtay not for me, wait on the Lady: Ile follow immediately.
sp.l: What ailes me? let me ſee
What is the cauſe of ſuch an alteration
I find within me: doubtleſs it is Love.
To whom? to whom but to the worthieſt
And ſweeteſt Lucora? Take heed, tis dangerous▪
A ſudden ruine ſo will ſeiſe my friendſhip,
And prove my former proteſtations
Feign'd untruths. Cannot the noble name
Of young Carionil prevent me? No,
Nor certainty of all the evil wills
Of all the friends I have;
Were both our better Genius Orators,
And here embraced faſt my knees, and wept
Miraculous tears (to quench the riſing flames
Lucora's irreſiſtible eyes have kindled
In me, or to drown this late impreſsion Love
Hath ſeald upon my heart) I'de be as remorſeleſs
As the moſt ſtern and unremoved Scythian,
And deafer then the people that inhabit
Near the Egyptian Cataracts of Nile.
But I am baſe, baſe to infringe the knot
Of amity a long and ſerious knowledge
Of each other hath tyed betwixt us. Twere ſafer
Sayling with drunken Mariners between
Hard Sylla and Charybdis, then to ſuffer
My much divided thoughts, and forth of them
To work ſuch a concluſion to my paſsions,
As might hereafter confirm me noble in
Th' opinion of the world: but I'me moſt ignorant,
And know not what to do. Wood I were ſo
Diſtraught, that my own ſelf I could not know.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Sweet Miſtris, your bounty will become
An envy unto future times.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: So let your love Sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: But ſpeak (my Dear) what happy day ſhall give
A fair concluſion unto all my wiſhes?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: What haſte good ſervant?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Nay be not angry Sweet.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Madam (and pleaſe you) your own good ſervants deſire to ſhew your Worſhips ſome pretty paſtime.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: It pleaſes us well: when begins it?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Eene preſently; Ile goe and tell them all what a good woman you are.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: This is not uſual with you?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Indeed Servant ſo ſeldom, that I remember not the like:
Sure tis for your entertainment; they think I have
Been a niggard of it, and help to make it out.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You are too good.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: So you can never be.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: And yet I will not fail to do my beſt.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: I pray you do not (dear Lorece) for tis a good reſolution.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I ſee we ſhall have ſome odde thing.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: I wiſh Sir▪ it may prove worthy your laughter.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: My fair Vandona, I believe you will have your deſire.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Iaques is among them: he may move you.

sp.speaker: Iaq.

l.hi: An'ether of you ask what's here, tis a Mask
Which we Actors do hope will content you:
If not, when it ends let us all part friends,
And of your attention go in and repent you.

sp.p: I hope your Worſhips will ſay I have pronounc'd this well enough.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: To my content honeſt Iaques.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: I'me glad you like it.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Come Hymen, thou fellow that always wear'ſt yellow,
Draw near in thy Frock of Saffron;
Once more I ſay appear before this gentleman here,
And this Lady in the white apron.
If the boy thou doſt bring hath a voice fit to ſing,
Lets have a merry new Ballet:
Begin thou the Song, and it will not be long
(We hope) before he will follow't.

sp.speaker: Hymen.
sp.l: Say, Boy, who are fit to be
Ioyn'd into an unity?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: They that will permit their wives
To live pleaſant quiet lives,
And will never entertain
Thoughts of jealouſie, if vain.

sp.speaker: Hym.
sp.l: Now Boy let this couple hear
What ſhould be the womans care.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A wife ſhould be ſecret, true,
Moſt obedient, and no ſhrew;
Should obey her husbands will,
While therein ſhe finds no ill.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Such a Wife and husband too
We do wiſh both him and you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Prithee Sweet lets be married this afternoon, and this ſhall be our Epithalamion.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Stay my leiſure good ſervant: t'will not belong.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Now if you pleaſe to caſt a glance Hither, ye ſhall ſee us dance:
sp.l: Fidlers play, begin and ſtrike: What ye ſee do not diſlike.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What a mad toy tis Miſtris!

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Iaques! this day uſe my wine-cellar, you and your company
May be as free in it as you will.

sp.speaker: Hym.
sp.l: Her Ladyſhip ſayes well: Good now ho lets go thither,
Without more ado.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Goodman Wedlock, where was your mind marle? Is there not a piece behind yet? Ile not budge a foot till I have diſcharg'd it.

sp.speaker: Hym.
sp.p: Out with it then.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Mr. Marriage, put me not out with your grining: for an you do all's ſpoil'd.

lg.l: Gentleman and Madam, you have ſeen
What our Mask and performance hath been:
If you like both tis well; and if but one,
Of the other wood we had done none.
For clapping of hands we care not two chips;
We are ſatisfied if you joyn your lips.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I thank you all.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: And ſo do I: you now may go.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: And ſo we muſt, for I ha done. All's done: this laſt (what do you call,) was the full end of it.

sp.speaker: Hym.
sp.p: Why go we not?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I am very dry with ſinging and dancing.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Follow me to the wine-cellar.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: You muſt keep your promiſe: you are expected by this.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Lady, I ki •• your hand: This is my vale as often as I come.
Ile ſeal my welcome on your lips. Farewell widow.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Remember my ſervice to your brother.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Command me any thing.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: The tedious winter of my many griefs
Her calmer heavenly breath hath now blown over;
And all my tears and ſighes are now converted
Into a happineſs will ſoon be perfect.
The gallant Courtier Paris Alexander
(When he had ſtole the young Atrides Bride,
The ſiſter of the two Tindarides,
And with great triumphs entred into Troy)
Was ſad and melancholy unto me.
How wiſe the Fates are! Ere we can obtain
Perfect frnition of the thing we love,
We muſt break through great difficulties & tedious,
Unto the end that we may more eſteem
And prize our happineſs when we atchieve it.
Thanks (excellent Lady) for your gracious promiſe:
May every Lover henceforth bleſs your tongue.
• he hath prefix'd this hour to be the time
Wherein I ſhall out-grow all hope, and fix
Upon the proudeſt height of fortunes wheel.
Hail happy hour! This is her chamber window,
And this the door whereby ſhe muſt eſcape.
Shine well ye ſtars, and let this project find
Your influences to a lover kind.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.p: See Madam, he is come: My Lord Tucapelo has not treſpas'd on a minute.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then is our parting near: your new ſervant hath prevented your journey.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Nentis!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Moſt honoured Tucapelo, I am here
In preſence to give anſwer to my Love.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Are you ready worthieſt Lady?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I am, my Love.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Neglect your Jewels: Gamara ſhall ſupply you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I care for nothing if I have but you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Deſcend (my Dear) each minute is an age
Until I crown my joyes with your poſſeſſion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I come. Nentis farewell: report that my
Eſcape was uuto thee unknown, and that
I ſtole away when thou waſt faſt aſleep:
I would not have thee blam'd for me. Excuſe
Me to my father all the wayes I have
Inſtructed thee in.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Cinthia, triumph; and let thy brother hear
His eyes did never witneſs ſuch a ſtealth:
Be proud in thy pale luſtre, and make known,
Apollo doth tell tales, but thou relſt none.
Not yet! how tedious ſeems a moment!
Delayes in Love
Would raiſe impatience in Olympick Iove.
But ſhe is entred! welcome ſweet Lucora,
Above expreſsion welcome, my crown of joy
I would not change for an imperial Scepter.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I am moſt happy in your love (dear friend)
sp.p: Thanks good Nentis: My woman cannot go with's.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Then farewell Nentis.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.p: May the propitious heavens crown both your heads with all fair fortune.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Our thanks go with you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It is your promiſe, Sir, that I ſhall live
Without contradiction in my Religion,
Enjoy my conſcience freely: your vow was ſolemn.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I do acknowledge it, and will perform it.
sp.p: —True—not to be denied, what a great froſt chils my affection!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then Ile be confident.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You may:
I am amaz'd, and loſt within a wonder.
Let me conſider; have I cauſe to love
A Lady that hath ſo much neglected me,
That ſhe hath prefer'd a Negro? And tis likely
(When ſhe knowes me) will care as little for me
As ere ſhe did, and (if ſhe meets with one
Of this complexion I feign) conferre
Her perfect love upon the ſlave? Tis clear,
I have no reaſon to do it, neither will I;
For I am free, know liberty again:
This poor unworthineſs in her hath loos'd me.
Would it not be a weakneſs in me (let me argue it)
To beſtow my ſelf upon a woman of
So obſtinate a nature, that ſhe lov'd me leſs
When ſhe believ'd that for her ſake I had
Done violence upon my ſelf? It would be
A matchleſs one, beyond example, and which
Future times would admire, but not parallel.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Come, ſhall we hence? delay is dangerous.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No; be it what it will.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: VVe muſt not ſtay here long.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Nor will we.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Alas! what ailes my noble Tucapelo?
You had not wont to anſwer me ſo ſlightly.
Do you not love me ſtill?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The heavens forbid! I am Lucora.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I do confeſs you are, but muſt deny
I love you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I could endure your Sword with better eaſe:
Us't, and revenge what ignorant ill I have
Committed againſt you. I had rather dye
By your dear hand, then to return from hence
With this ſtrong poyſon in my breaſt.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Kill you!
Lady, I would not do it to obtain
The Soveraignty of the Sea-parted Earth▪
Live many years in happineſs: I wiſh it
With all my ſoul, elſe may I dye unwept for.
But give me leave to leave you, and beſtow
Laughter, not tears for my inconſtancy.
Think me unworthy of your worthy ſelf;
For I cannot love you, nor will marry you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Surely you will. Have you a cauſe to be
So mercileſs unto a paſſionate Lady,
One that ſo truly wonders at your worths?
I pray you (Sir) jeſt not ſo ſolemnly:
Thunder is Muſick in my ears to this.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I do not: credit me (moſt fair Lucora)
I am in earneſt, nor would I ſpend the time
In words. Shall I call Nentis?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Rather call Baſiliskes to look me dead
Then her, to help to mourn your unkind parting.
O! do not thus: wherein am I deform'd
So ſuddenly, that you ſo ſoon ſhould leave me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: This is a trouble to your ſelf: you cannot
Speak words enough to make me yours.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Can I not ſpeak ſufficiently! Then I
Will try if there be Magick in my knees:
Look (Sir) a Lady kneels to you for love, She kneels.
To whom the nobleſt in the Realm have ſu'd.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: All is in vain.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Thou man (that art more laſting in thy fury
Then the Egyptian wonder through the ſtormes
Of many bleak tempeſtuous winters)
Say worthleſs man, if it becomes thee well
To let a loving Lady kneel to thee,
And thou be mercileſs and not raiſe her • p.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I pray you riſe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And will you then be reconcil'd unto me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No I cannot.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then I will turn a Statue.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I pray you leave me and forget me ever:
Henceforth you ſhall not ſee me any more,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Not ſee you any more!
O faithleſs man and full of perjuries!
Thy nature is tranſparent, thou art falſe
As is the ſmooth-fac'd Sea, which every wind
Diſturbes; a falſe Barbarian, and born under
Deceitful Mercury. A Britain would
Rather have died then thus have wronged me:
Thou art inhumane, and mayeſt boaſt the conqueſt.
Tell your moſt ſalvage countrey-men this Act,
(If the juſt God of Seas revenge me not)
And number it 'mongſt your proud cruelties.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Be pacifi'd: I pray you leave this rage.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: When I am dead I ſhall, and not before,
And that ſhall not be long; For thou ſhalt ſee me,
Mercileſs man thou ſhalt, and adde that to
Thy bloody conqueſts; boaſt how a ſlighted Lady▪
For thy unkindneſs made her ſelf away.
This hand (wherewith I would have given my ſelf
To thee) ſhall take me from my miſery.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Hold: I am Carionil.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How! ſay that again.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I am Carionil.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That breath hath rais'd me, and made me my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I counterfeited the Negro to obtain you,
The wiſhed period of my griefes; and might,
But will not love that woman that ſhall ſcorn
All my endeavours, and entertain a ſtranger,
An Ethiopian, and prefer him, no:
Judg (fair Lucora) if I have not cauſe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Yes, yes you have: But now you do not need
More of your Rhetorick to diſſwade me from you.
There are not in the world temptations
Can make me yours: I cannot give a reaſon,
Tis in my nature, and a ſecret one.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I am glad it is ſo.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: This is the happieſt hour
My life did ever paſs, and quickly chang'd.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I rejoyce at the alteration: Madam, you ſhall
Command me to do any thing but marry you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then I command you never move me more.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I will obey you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Now you may call Nentis:
She is not yet in bed; I ſee a light yet.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Moſt willingly.
Nentis, Nentis.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: What's the matter, marle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Come down.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: I wonder much: I come (Madam.)

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You will be ſecret, Sir, of what hath paſt?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You may be confident I will.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I elſe ſhall ſuffer much in my honour.
Women! take heed: the men whom you deny
May win you to be theirs by Policy:
They Proteus-like will vary ſhapes, until
Beyond their wiſhes they have plac'd their will.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Your woman's come: Good night.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Good night (Sir)
Nentis, I now will never paſs the Seas:
Tucapelo is become Carionil.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.p: Amazement ceaſeth me!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Anon thou ſhalt know all.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.p: I hope that now you will be rul'd by your friends, and take the Lord Falorus to your husband.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hang husbands!

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.p: The Gods bleſs them all I ſay, and ſend me a good one.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Let's to bed: lock the door after you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: How joy fully the birds ſalute the morn,
Warbling a welcome from their gentle throats!
But I am of another mind (poor maid!)
Aurora doth no ſooner bluſh upon
The world, but I make my complaints afreſh.
I am in love, and for my wretched State
Can blame no body but ſiniſter Fate.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Well met (Anclethe) I will hide no longer
My ſelf in this diſguiſe. Again thou ſhalt
Be my Anclethe: wilt thou be my Boy,
And ſing me ſongs, as thou hadſt wont to do?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: You have obtain'd your Miſtris I ſee, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I have not (boy) nor will I ſeek her more:
Some other time thou ſhalt receive the ſtory.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: My hour is come: dear Cupid be my aid.
And will you never have another Sir?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I do not know Anclethe, but if I have,
She muſt not be ſo obſtinate as this.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: But ſay a Lady of a noble houſe
(One that is not unhandſom) were in love
With you, did love you violently (my Lord)
Would you not pity her, but be unkind?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Boy, I do know what tis to love in vain
So well, and what a miſery is in it,
That if ſhe were but reaſonably well,
She ſhould not grieve for me, indeed ſhe ſhould not.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: You are moſt noble: old Philoſophy
Never defin'd a virtue which you want.
There is a Lady Sir, and not ill-favour'd,
Born of an ancient honourd family,
So much in love with you, that if you do
Refuſe her (my Lord) you do deny her life.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What is ſhe cal'd Anclethe?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: My Lord, my Commiſsion doth not reach ſo farre;
She'd have her name conceal'd until y'ave ſeen her.
Tomorrow morning you may meet her here:
She with a gentleman (a friend of hers)
VVill here expect you about ten a clock.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: VVell, I will ſee her (boy) and if I find
Her anſwer thy report, I will be kind.
He that neglects a loving Lady for
VVeak cauſes, may the Gods that man abhorre.

div.stage: A Banquet ſet forth: Then enter Polidacre, Antiphila, Servants and M • ſitians.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: YOu will pardon a ſudden entertainment.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I hope we need not complement.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: You do inſtruct me.
Sit down (my ſweet Antiphila) and taſte.
Fill wine:
All health and happineſs to you (dear Miſtris.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A true return of loyal thanks.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Play a more merry tune: I do abhor
What ever reliſheth of melancholy.
Sing, the ſpheres are dull—
Apply it to your ſelf that beſt deſerve it.

lg.l: The Spheres are dull, and do not make
Such Muſick as my ears will take:
The ſlighted Birds may ceaſe to ſing,
Their chirpings do not grace the ſpring:
The Nightingal is ſad in vain,
I care not to hear her complain:
While I have ears and you a tongue,
I ſhall think all things elſe go wrong.
The Poets feign'd that Orpheus could
Make ſtones to follow where he would:
They feign'd indeed, but (had they known
Your voice) a truth they might have ſhown.
All inſtruments moſt ſadly go,
Becauſe your tongue excels them ſo:
While I have ears, and you a tongue,
I ſhall think all things elſe go wrong.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tis pretty.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Reiterate again your yielding, Lady,
And once more let your breath perfume thoſe words.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, I am yours.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: And I my fair Antiphila's, your tongue
Hath made me happy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: May your joy laſt long.

div.head: Scena ſecunda.
div.stage: Enter Philander and Roſinda in womens apparel.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: How glad I am to ſee you like your ſelf!
Dear mother; pardon an exceſs of joy.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: Such ſignes of true affection need no pardon.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir, here's a Letter for you.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: For me! from whom? the hand reſolves me;
Preſent my ſervice to the Lady that ſent it.
Tell her, ere long I will come kiſs her hands.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I will Sir.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Mother, I writ unto Antiphila,
And did deſire her (for guerdon of my love)
To hold me ſecond in her thoughts, and (if
She married not my father) to have me.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: She may perform
What ſhe believ'd would never come to paſs.

body.head: The Letter.
body.p: SIR, I confeſs I am not contracted, and that I told you ſo to make you deſiſt. I ſhould be exceeding ungrateful to deny you ſo ſmall a requeſt. There is nothing hinders me from being yours, but your Father: And I ſolemnly vow unto you, that (if I have not him) you ſhall have me. But let not this beget any hope in you; ▪for (if I be not his) it ſhall be his refuſal. Let it onely manifeſt ſo much, that (had I never ſeen him) I could have lov'd you moſt truly. I pray you, let this ſuffice, and uſe me ſo. Chooſe another Miſtris, and let me be her ſecond: You will love me well enough, if you love another better. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: What writ you to her (Son) concerning her
Pro •• ſſing a contract betwixt us two?
〈…〉 my rage I met with Tandorix,
〈…〉 him of his life;
〈…〉 he was a woman▪
And for a Gentleman cal'd Perimont,
(Who often had deni'd to marry her)
That habit did aſſume, thereby to learn
More eaſily what did prevent her joy,
And whether he affected any other.
Thus I your being kept unknown.

sp.speaker: Roſin.
sp.l: I'me gald you did ſo.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: You do well, Mother, to wear a mask: you ſhall
Thereby be ſure to be conceal'd untill
You find the fitteſt opportunity
Your ſelf (unto my Father) to reveal.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: What will become of me (unfortunate man)
Who needs muſt live in fire▪ or live in ſhame?
I know not what to ſpeak nor what to do,
Both fear and grief do ſo confound my ſences▪
I fear to wrong Carionil ſo much
As to be traiterous againſt our friendſhip;
And griefs unſufferable endure for the
Faireſt of Ladies, incomparable Lucora:
I would ſhe had been kind unto my friend,
Unto him then I never had prov'd falſe;
Nor will I: I will rather ſearch out frozen
Climates, and lie whole nights on hills of Ice,
Or rather will take powerfull potions, and ſleep
Out thoſe unpleaſant houres I have to live;
But then I ſhall not ſee that beauty: who
But ſenceleſs frantickes would have thoughts ſo poor?
My reaſon forſakes the government of this
Weak frame, and I am falne into diſorder.
Oh! I could ſigh my body into air,
And weep't into a Lake, if mercileſs nature
Had made it of a ſubſtance ſuitable
Unto my wiſh now: methinks I could level
A Promontory into a Province, and tread
The centre through to read the deſtinies
Of ſouthern ſtars, and bleſs their fortunes that
Are born under their light; for (I am confident)
Their influences are more mild then ours.
There is no other Fate can fall on me
Shall awe me now; I will be proud and daring
As the ambitious waves, when wrathful blaſts
Of Northern windes do hoiſt them violently
Againſt the higheſt cloudes, and rather will
Deſtroy my ſelf then wrong Carionil.

div.head: Scena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Cleanthe in womans apparel, and Phygionis.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And ſerv'd my ſiſter well to leave her ſo.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: How much (dear Madam) have you impoveriſhed
Mens cies, by hiding your perfections
In their apparel? indeed I flatter not,
I do not know the Lady owns ſo much beauty.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: If my Carionil will like me, then
I ſhall attain the end of my deſires:
May I appear but lovely in his eye,
And what I ſeem in others I will ſlight.
But (good Phygionis) tell me I prethee
In your affection what ſucceſs you have.
Is Nentis won, or do you hope ſhe will?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: She's mine, we are contracted.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Joy wait on you,
And make your lives of many years paſs pleaſant.
Is it not ten? are all the clocks grown envious
Againſt my bliſs, and will not let me know
How nigh his coming is? for I eſteem
My ſelf moſt happy in his company.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: This is the place Anclethe nam'd.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Madam he's here.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Be friend me my good ſtars!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Here is a Lady and a matchleſs one!
Wood two years ſince I had beheld this beauty,
When firſt I came from Spain and had my heart free,
Then many a ſad day had been merry unto me,
For unto her Lucora ſhould have yielded.
Sweet Lady, you that are the faireſt creature
Nature did ever form, vouchſafe ſo much
Of happineſs unto me as to give
Me liberty to touch your lips—do you
Know me? and have your ears ere heard
So poor a name as is Carionil?
But I am much miſtook; you are not ſhe
Whom here I was to meet: I needs muſt doubt
The fates did not intend me ſuch a joy.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I am.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Deceiv'd Pythagoras! hadſt thou but dream't
The ſweetneſs of this voice, the muſick of
The Spheres thou never hadſt recorded. Speak,
Faireſt and beſt of Ladies, let me hear
If you have ſo unmatch'd a pity in you
As to look on me with a friendly eye.
Can you love me?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Moſt noble Sir, I do moſt violently.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: If that to live with you detain'd me not,
I ſhould be griev'd that my joy for ſo great
A fortune did not ſtupifie my ſenſes,
And caſt me into an eternal ſleep.
Where is Anclethe? he is much to blame
In not attending you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Whom ſpeak you of dear Sir?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My boy.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I do not know a boy of that name truly:
Nor (I think) is there.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You do amaze me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: You may believe me, Sir, for I am he.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Wonders in Riddles!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I am your Page Anclethe, and ſiſter to
Lucora, who for love attended you
Diſguis'd, becauſe (I found) for the great enmity
Between our families) my father never
Would give me where I would beſtow my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Your Nurſe did ſteal you when you was a child?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Moſt true: This gentleman her ſon, my friend,
Occaſioned my eſcape, by giving me
A knowledge of my birth. His true relation
Can vindicate me from ſuſpicion.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I need it not:
Were you not ſhe (as I believe you are)
And mean of birth, I ſhould account my ſelf
A gainer by you. Sir, you have done that
Hath plac'd you in my heart among thoſe friends
For whoſe ſakes I my life will ſacrifice.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: My Lord, you do indebt me to your ſervice:
In your acquaintance I ſhall be moſt honour'd.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Sir, if you pleaſe he will relate my Story.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: By no means: keep it for your father, when
You do diſcloſe your ſelf. But can you pardon
Thoſe incivilities I did commit
When you was Anclethe?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Wrong not your ſelf: you did make more of me
Then I deſerv'd, or could.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: But why, my ſweet Cleanthe, would you not
Let me know who you was before?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Dear Sir, I ſaw how violent you was
In your affection to my careleſs ſiſter,
And had no hope you would leave her for me:
And (if you did obtain her) meant to do
What my diſaſtrous fate ſhould prompt me to.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Sweeteſt of all your ſex.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: But (if you never got her, and orecame
Her obſtinacy) to declare my ſelf;
If not (but Love had triumph'd in your fall)
I'de not have liv'd to ſee your Funeral.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: The Gods requite this goodneſs, and make me worthy
Of you, my dear Cleanthe; I contract
My ſelf upon your lips: which we will perfect
Ere you own publikely your Father, for
The enmity will make him charge you otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I pray you let us.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: A thouſand thanks, come ſhall we walk (fair Miſtreſs)?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Concluſions fair the fates to them do give
Who conſtant in their loves, and faithful live.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Stay, dear Cleanthe, here is my friend, he ſhall
Partake my joy; well met my beſt Falorus.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: It ſeems you are not Tucapelo now:
Where is Lucora? have you married her?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No, I have not, friend.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Refrain:
I am your enemy, embrace me not,
Receive my ſword, and peace this heart (Carionil.) Gives his ſword.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: He hath not yet deſcri'd you:
Withdraw a little (dear Miſtreſs) Sir, I pray you
To bear her company, for who can tell
What in this phrenſie he may do?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Hereabouts we will await your leiſure.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What ailes my friend? let me but know the man
Is cauſe of this diſorder in you, and
He ſhall not ſee the gray-ey'd morning break
From th' oriental Mountains any more:
Let me partake of that unwieldy grief
Hath bowd my friend ſo much beneath himſelf.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Leave complements Carionil, and make
A paſſage for my ſoul, that it may leave
So vile a habitation as this body;
And (when I'me dead) rip out my heart and in't
Survey my fault, for I want words, and have
Not impudence enough to tell it you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: O what might be the cauſe this matchleſs frame
And worthieſt Cabinet that ever man
Inclos'd his ſecrets in, is ſo diſturb'd!
Noble Falorus, think to whom you ſpeak,
It is Carionil, whoſe life you do
Make burthenous to him by the ſuſpicion
Of wronging him whom you have ever lov'd.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: You do deceive your ſelf; I lately have
Tranſgres'd againſt our league of amity:
If you deſire to be a happy man,
And to enjoy what moſt you ſeek, be kind
Unto your ſelf, and run my body through.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Can I be happy and Falorus dead!
No, I ſhould live a deſolater life
Then ere the ſtricteſt Anchorite hath done,
And wear my body to an Anatome,
For real ſorrow at ſuch a dire miſhap:
Live then (my friend) and may you number daies
Until Arithmetick grow faint, and leave you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: You know not how much hurt you wiſh your ſelf.
Would you torment me twice? If not, forget
Falorus utterly, and let me dye.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I underſtand you not.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Would you have me blaſt my own fame by ſpeaking
My fault? And have me Executioner
Unto my ſelf?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Releaſe your Soul of all her griefes, and ſay
From whence your ſorrows have original.
Have you not oft told me of my impatiency?
Give me now leave to be as plain with you:
The angry winds never enrag'd the ſeas
So much as ſome ſmall grief hath done my friend.
I do conjure you by our former loves
(For ſure not long ſince we were friends indeed)
To let me know why you are thus diſtemper'd:
I do not fear but I ſhall free you from
This paſsion ſo precipitate and dangerous.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: You are moſt good, and get your ſelf, Carionil,
A name above the ableſt character,
None (like it) can decipher you; and would
I alwayes had continued Falorus,
Then I yet had remain'd your friend. But (if
You needs will know the reaſon of my fury)
Draw out the ſword, that (when you have receiv'd it)
Your hand, and not your words may ſtrike me dead.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Be not importun'd longer; eaſe your heart:
For (credit me) I grieve to ſee you thus.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I am in love, ſuppoſe the reſt, and kill me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: VVith Lucora?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Too true, now curſe me into duſt, and with
Your breath diſperſe me into aire: but ſpare me,
Chide me not for my falſhood, and inflict
But one puniſhment on me, and be that the ſword;
Yet hear me ſpeak one word or two before.
I have not woo'd her, nor have ſought performance
Of that free promiſe that her father made me,
But faithfully have temporiz'd with him;
Nor did I willingly conſent unto
This paſſion, it did ſeiſe me violently.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Be you more calme, take her (Falorus) you have
A liberty for me, I ſpeak in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Then all is well, return my ſword (dear friend)
Carionil, I will not hinder thee:
My name ſhall not be blaſted in thy ſighes;
Fall worthleſs man, tis pity I ſhould live.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: VVhat mean you (my Falorus?) for heavens ſake leave,
And your own light raſhly extinguiſh not:
I for Lucora do not care, and have
All my affection unto her recal'd,
And am engag'd unto another Lady;
I ſtole her from her chamber in my diſguiſe,
And then (bethinking me how ſhe had us'd me)
I told her that I would not have a Lady
VVho would prefer a Moor before me. Her
Slighting of me made me to leave her ſo.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Is this not policy to delay my death?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: If ere you found me falſe, believe me not.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: It then is true?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Moſt true, Falorus.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Licence me (friend) now to embrace you; well met
(Carionil) and welcomer indeed
Then ever yet man was unto me: I
Will live and owe my life unto you, and (when
You pleaſe) I for your ſake will lay it down:
Freely I may Lucora now adore;
And (rather then to loſe her) I will try
All waies that are contain'd in policie.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: But ſay ſhe never will conſent?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I am
Moſt confident ſhe will to pleaſe her Father:
But (if ſhe ſhould not) I could ſuffer it;
'Twas not my Love made me thus paſſionate,
It was becauſe in it I wronged you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Did you not marke (when you did ſee me firſt)
A joy unuſual ſit upon my brow?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I had ſo much of ſorrow in my heart,
That with it all my ſences were poſſeſt.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: But you perceiv'd I had left my diſguiſe;
What out of it did you collect?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I thought
Lucora had deſcri'd you, and you had
A peremptory denial to your ſuit.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Sir, ſeeing you had made a fair concluſion,
And meaſuring each minute for an hour
Until I were with you, I rudely come
Uncal'd for to you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Ever moſt welcome my Cleanthe; friend,
This is the Lady I did mention to you,
She was Anclethe, b • t is ſiſter to
The Miſtreſs of you • thoughts, and cal'd Cleanthe,
Whom long ſince all her friends believed loſt,
And have theſe many years left mourning for.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: A ſtrange diſcovery and admirable!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Some other time command the hiſtory;
This mutually among our ſelves we'l ſpend.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Lady, account me ſervant to your vertues,
And you, Sir, may command Falorus alwaies.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Your love will honour me (moſt noble Lord.)

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Sir, I for you will interceſſion make
Unto my ſiſter, and do hope ſhall proſper:
I will make known how much you are her ſervant,
And what affection my ears have witneſſed;
For I (unſeen to you) did hear what paſſ'd.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: You will oblige me everlaſtingly.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Now let us walk.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Whoſoever loyal friendſhip doth regard,
With fair events the Gods will him reward.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p:
I have a Licence for my Lady, & the brave gallant Miſtreſs Lorece, But it coſt too much a conſcience,
I wood a writ five times as much for halfe I gave for it: But t'is the faſhion among great ones, ſo they have their wills they care not at how dear a rate they buy them. This marriage is like Chriſtmas, when it comes it brings good cheer with't, we have fat Veniſon, hold belly hold: and wine I am ſure we ſhall want none, for the Vintner had twenty pounds on me this morning. I ha beſpoke a merry company of Fidlers; O they are boon fellows! and there will be old dancing, for I mean to ſweat my doublet quite through ere I leave.
Madam, her'es the Licenſe your Worſhips ſent me for, the Parſon and this will make all ſure.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Tis well done Iaques, for this, be thou the Neptune of the Cellar, raiſe a tempeſt, and drown who ever doth go down the ſtaires;
Like old Silenus behave thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: When we have din'd, lets go to my Lord Polidacres, and invite that houſe.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: We will (my dear Widow.)

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Twill be a merry time I ſee.

div.head: Scena ſexta.
div.stage: Enter Polidacre, Lucora, Antiphila, and Nentis.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I wonder we have not ſeen the Ethiopian Lord to day.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: He'l not be long abſent.
Lucora, thou haſt my heart for thy conſent:
Falorus is a worthy Gentleman,
And one of an approved faſhion,
He doth deſerve a Princeſs; my Lucora,
I know his nature is moſt noble, elſe
I would not move thee for him, and (although
The time is not expir'd) will you ſteal
So much from age, and be his wife? I long
To ſee thee well beſtow'd.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: VVhat ere you pleaſe t'command I will perform.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Here is Falorus! welcome my Lord, I ſhall
Shortly ſay my ſon; my daughter I have won,
And when I pleaſe, unto you ſhe will give
Away herſelf.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: You are moſt noble:
But can you (faireſt Lady) look ſo low
As is Falorus? can there be ſuch a vertue
Of rare humility within you, that
You thus confer affection upon me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My Lord, my father deſires to make me yours;
And I have learnt ſo much obedience,
As willingly to do what he commands.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I wiſh I could (moſt excellent Lucora)
Thanke you in all the languages are worth
Your dear attention, you have made me ſo
Exceeding happy, I envy not his wealth
That ownes the inhauſtible mines of fam'd Peru.

sp.speaker: Luco.
sp.l: I thank you for this love, and have a hope
Requite you Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: My joy hath dul'd my ſenſes.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Now brother! have I not ended happily?
Vandona is my own: We onely want
The ceremony Ecleſiaſtical.
My Lord, I am your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I have a Miſtris got, the richeſt beauty
Great Brittain ever was renowned for.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Much, very much y faith; have you won her
For whom hopeful Carionil did dye?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I won her not (Lorece) her fathers deſire
Meeting with her conſent, have made her mine.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Siſter, you have been a ſtranger to me, I pray you be not ſo.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.p: You ſhall ſee me oftner.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Thou maiſt be Mercury, and I will glory
Thou art my brother.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Madam, I'm very glad to meet you here.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And I as joyful of your company.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Wonders▪ Carionil's alive again, and here.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: For ſome ſtrange end he did give forth his death:
But what yong beauteous Ladie's that?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It is a face worthy of admiration.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Riſe Lady: kneel not unto me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Then I were moſt unfit to be your Child.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: How▪ my daughter that was loſt?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Yes my Lord, and beg your bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: May the good heavens make of thee (my daughter)
(If you be ſhe) an old and happy woman.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I am a Siſter to you: Spare ſome time
For me to ſhew how much I do rejoyce
At this unlook'd for good: none of your kin
(Fair Siſter) are more glad then I to ſee you,
Whom we had never hope to ſee: I am
Moſt proud to be alli'd unto
So excellent a creature as you are.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: I am moſt joyful of your love.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We are moſt glad to ſee you ſafe.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: As if you were our Siſter.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: My thanks (ſweet Ladies)

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Deareſt Cleanthe, confirm thy father in
His joy: relate thy life, that out of it
I may grow confident thou art my daughter.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Lady, leave that to me: My Lord (and if
You with her ſilence can ſo long diſpence)
I would do that.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: He is my Nurſes Son, to whom (my Lord)
I owe all thanks for my eſcape.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Sir, when you pleaſe you may begin.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: What, not a gentleman! I am undone,
But muſt be ſecret in't.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: My Lord.
This Ladies Nurſe, my mother, had a Sonne
Older then the Lady Cleanthe is by ſeven years;
Whom ſhe did love ſo extraordinarily,
That for his ſake ſhe foulely er'd from vertue:
She thought it was an eaſie thing for her
(If that their lives attained to thoſe years)
To make your daughter wife unto her ſon;
Which is the cauſe ſhe privily eſcap'd.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Moſt ſtrange!

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: By chance I heard this of my brother, who
Told me (againſt my mothers ſtrict command)
What a great marriage he ſhould have, and that
Cleanthe was the daughter of a Lord,
Your Honours child,
Whom all we thought but of a mean deſcent:
(For ſhe had won the country to believe
That ſhe did find her in the open field:)
I pittying her hard chance, did tell her all,
And promis'd her I would attend upon her,
Until ſhe had her parents happy made
With knowledge of her ſafety.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: The reſt I muſt relate:
Dear Sir, be kind, and (if I have done ought
You ſhall diſlike) pardon my firſt offence;
I was no ſooner come to town, but ſaw
This noble Gentleman, with whom ſo violently
I fell in love, that for his ſake (pray pardon me)
My own apparel I did lay away,
And did become his Page: And (when I did
Diſcloſe my ſelf) he kindly did requite me.
In brief we are contracted,
I did not well without you to do thus;
But your forgiveneſs, Sir, I cannot doubt:
He told me that there was a difference
Between our families, and therefore you
(If your conſent was ask'd) would never yield.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Wood I were it'h Cellar, I care not for theſe drie and tedious tales.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Whether I ſhould or no I cannot tell,
But I am glad that it hath chanced thus;
This match an ancient diſcord will conclude,
And may the Gods be favourable to it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Moſt Worthy Lord, my faithful thankes.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Here alſo is a ring which by
Your Father (my Lord Falorus) was given her,
When at the Font he for her anſwer'd;
She wo'rt about her neck when ſhe was ſtolne.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I know it well, and am confident
Thou art my loſt Cleanthe: Be his wife,
And may the heavens make up the match moſt fortunate.
Carionil, I now am glad I have
A man ſo honour'd to my ſon in law.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My Lord (if that I can perform my will)
You never ſhall repent your daughters choice.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I do not doubt I ſhall. Now I would know
Why your death was reported.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I was in love long which your eldeſt daughter▪
The fair Lucora, but could never win her;
Brought almoſt to deſpair I did aſſume
The habit and colour of a Negro.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Then you was Tucapelo.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I was indeed▪
Knowing ſhe had refuſ'd the greateſt Marriages,
And many of the handſomeſt of the Kingdome,
I fully did believe ſhe never would
Like any man of this Complexion,
And therefore feign'd my ſelf an Ethiopian.
But firſt gave out my death, and that unto
My ſelf I had done violence, for her.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Surely, he will not do ſo unworthily
As to make mention of my fond affection.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: But all could not prevail.

sp.speaker: Luco.
sp.l: I am glad he ends ſo.

sp.speaker: Cario.
sp.l: And therefore I deſiſted wholly: which when
Anclethe ſaw (my ſweet Cleanthe now)
She did diſcloſe her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.l: I do perceive the Heavens intended you
Should reconcile our Families.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Her's love, and love agen: I wood ſome body would love me.

sp.speaker: Luco.
sp.l: My dear Siſter, you muſt not think me rude
Becauſe I do expreſs my love ſo fully.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: Be my Carionil;
All that •• e mine reſpect this Lady: For
I do intend to make her ſo.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: We are her Servants, and moſt joyfully
Shall kneel unto a Lady of her vertues.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: What Lady's that?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: She's masked, and I cannot gueſs.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Philander, this Lady is thy Siſter, the loſt

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Grow not to weak, my body, to contain (Cleanthe.
My ſoul within thee at theſe joyes:
Fair Siſter, I am glad that I can name
So beauteous a Lady as you are ſo;
For you the heavens be thanked.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Carionil's alive, and muſt be ſtyl'd your brother,
Cleanthe him hath choſe:
Perfect thy joyes (Philander) when thou wilt,
And hear their Hiſtories;
This Lady you muſt call mother.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But I muſt not.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This here I will;
Dear mother, now confirm my words.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: Welcome to life Roſinda: Thy face and beauty
I do remember well: But wherefore did you
Raiſe the report of your untimely death?

sp.speaker: Roſin.
sp.l: That at a fitter time. This give me leave
To ſpend in joy.
My dear Cleanthe (for I do believe
Becauſe thy father doth acknowledge thee,
Thou art Cleanthe my ſo long loſt daughter)
Never was mothers heart ſo light; I cannot
Utter my joyes, my tears muſt witneſs them.
To time I am indebted, that he hath
Spared my life untill I ſee thee ſafe.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I want expreſſion: But my life ſhall be
A comment on my heart, wherein you ſhall
Perceive what your Cleanthe is.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Now you are mine (fair Antiphila.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I will perform my promiſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Both your conſents I begge.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.l: How's this!

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: I did engage my ſelf,
That (if I were not yours) I would be his.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Then may the knot prove happy, and continue
A firm one, while the Gods do lend you breath.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: It is my wiſh.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Was you her ſervant too? Wife, chide me in ſecrer, I was forſworn.

sp.speaker: Roſ.
sp.l: We all are frail; Mortality may boaſt
Of ſtrength, but many concluſions deny it.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Away, I will have none of you, I will not begge.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: You ſhall not need, I (for his love and care
Unto my daughter) will give him means befitting
A Gentleman, which ſhall deſcend unto
His poſterity, poverty ſhall not ſpoil his fortune.

sp.speaker: Vandon.
sp.l: 'Tis nobly ſaid, If you do like him, take him ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Now I'm content.

sp.speaker: Phyg.
sp.p: My joy is great: My thanks (ſweet Miſtriſs) My Lord Polidacre, I am your grateful, though unworthieſt ſervant. Now, Miſtriſs, you ſhall know the policy I won your affections with; my affections being ſetled ſo high, and I poor, I made my ſelf Draculemion; But your promiſe, worthieſt Lord hath now enriched me.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O me! Was you that merry fellow? you have a parlous wit.

sp.speaker: Phyg.
sp.p: One thing I muſt crave of you.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: You ſhall obtain Sir.

sp.speaker: Phyg.
sp.p: That you will pardon my Mother.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: I do for your ſake.

sp.speaker: Luco.
sp.l: Since I perceive you in the bounteous way
Of granting Boons, Sir, I aſſume the boldneſs
To become a Petitioner to you.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.l: My dear Lucora freely ask, for I
Doubtleſſely ſhall conſent to thy demand.

sp.speaker: Luco.
sp.l: Seeing the gracious Heavens have bleſſed our houſe
With the recovery of my long loſt Siſter;
And ſince the powers divine have link'd her heart
To the affections of a noble Gentleman,
A marriage like to grace your honour'd Age
With hopeful Nephews; I humbly crave your licence
To enjoy the freedom of a ſingle life;
For I've no inclination to become
A ſubject unto Hymens glorious bondage.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.l: Remember (my Lucora) all your promiſes,
And ſuffer not your obſtinacy to cloud
The happineſs of this Evening.

sp.speaker: Falor.
sp.l: My excellent Miſtris, you have rais'd me neer
The Zenith of all happineſs, and will you
Now leave me on that mighty precipice,
To fall into a ſad Abyſs of miſery?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: My dear ſweet Siſter, give me leave to trouble you
With a few words aſide;
I ſaw the Lord Falorus for your ſake
(Between a great affection and firme friendſhip)
In as high a paſſion as you can imagine.
A noble and a faithful Lover to you;
He in his ſoul adores you, I am confident;
And I'm obliged by promiſe to become
His Interceſſor for your kind affection:
I do beſeech you therefore grace your Siſter
(Though bold, being younger, to importune you thus)
T'honor the Lord Falorus with your Love.

sp.speaker: Lucor.
sp.l: I dare not (my fair ſiſter) be ſo cruel
As to deny you in your firſt requeſt;
I'le entertain his flame and be his Bride.
I will be plain with you, had you been ſilent,
In a ſhip bound for Spain I had gone to night
With ſome Ladies of our neer kindred towards Lisbone,
And ſo avoided the Courtſhip of Falorus,
And all my Fathers continual importunities.
To make this eſcape more unexpected, and
The better to provide me for this journey,
I had conſented when my father pleas'd
To marry him; but your intreaties have
Prevail'd above all my reſolutions.

sp.speaker: Falor.
sp.l: Dear Madam, let me beſeech your aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Roſin.
sp.l: My Lord, I will deſire her, and am confident
I▪ ſhall obtain. I pray thee (my Lucora)
Submit to the intreaties of thy friends,
And let not thy refuſal of Falorus
Beget a ſad look on this happy evening.

sp.speaker: Lucor.
sp.l: Madam, you and my ſiſter ſhall overcome;
And though (my Lord Falorus) you may taxe me
For an obſtinate diſpoſition, you ſhall find me
Throughout my future dayes) to made amends,
And prove a very loving wife unto you.

sp.speaker: Falor.
sp.l: Now you have fixed me in a fortunate
And glorious life.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.l: I thank thee my Lucora.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Every body has his Sweetheart but I; one or other take pity on me, and let me not be a Cypher and ſtand here for nothing. I ſee the fault is in my years, otherwiſe Serving-men are not ſo ſlighted by Ladies.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.l: Let us withdraw; you all
Shall ſuppe with me to night, and we'l deſign
The happy day that ſhall each couple joyn.

sp.speaker: Cario.
sp.l: You that have Miſtriſſes, do not deſpair
To get them, be they nere ſo proud and fair;
One way or other (you have ſeen it done)
The Obſtinateſt Lady may be wone.

sp.speaker: Lucora.
sp.l: THe obſtinate Lady yet is obſtinate,
And (careleſs either of your love or hate)
She dares continue ſo: Nor will I beg
Some friend within to come with his low leg,
And's hat in's hand to woe your praiſe: It is
So poor, that I had rather hear you hiſs.
Our Poet bad's be bold, For's Play was good,
And that t'would take, if it was underſtood;
And ſo we are: For what's our fate we muſt
And will endure, be't lawful, or unjuſt.
Unto your juſtice we appeal, which lies
Within your hands: Do what you pleaſe, and riſe,

sp.speaker: Cleanth.
sp.l: O ſiſter! This is likely to ſpoil all:
Gentle Spectators, alſo give me leave.

lg.l: Ladies and Gentlemen, if we have ſaid
Ought that hath pleas'd your ears, or paſtime made▪
Our time we have ſpent well▪ but if that we
Have tedious been, and you did ſit and ſee
With we arineſs, our Poet will repent
That you this Comedy we did preſent.
Y'ave paid the Actors wel, we thank you & know it,
And wiſh that you would gratifie our Poet▪
He wants no money as the caſe now ſtands,
Yet • rayes you to be liberal of your hands.

div.p: Trappolin creduto Principe. OR TRAPPOLIN Suppos'd a Prince. An Italian TRAGE-COMEDY. The ſcene part of Italy. Written by Sir ASTON COKAIN.

row.cell: Son of the Duke of Savoy.
Hymen, Luna, Mars, Mercury, Iupiter, Venus, Saturn, Sol:

lg.l: GAllants, be't known as yet we cannot ſay
But this our Poet hath licens'd us to tell,
Ingenious Italy hath lik'd it well:
Yet is it no tranſlation; for he nere
But twice in Venice did it ever hear▪
There it did take, and he doth hope (if you
Have your old humors) it will pleaſe here too
He ſwears he hath not ſpoil'd it, and proteſt
We think it good, though he doth none ot'h beſt
You often have heard worſe it'h houſe before,
And had we made the Prologue wee'd ſay more
That labour he hath ſav'd us, cauſe he wood
No partial friend ſhould crie it up for good;
An excellent new Comedy as you ſay,
When you have ſeen't, he ſo will judge his pla •
He is not peremptory, like to ſome
Who think that all is beſt from them doth come
Ladies and Gentlemen, you that do know
To cenſure rightly as you think ſo do:
Our Poet ſcornes to beg your hands, yet ſaith,
That at the end if he the favour hath,
This ſhall not be his laſt, that he'l endeavou •
To gratifie you ſhortly with another:
How ere it takes, he for your preſence ſends
His thankes by me, and hopes we ſhall par • friends.

sp.p: MY wench Flametta is a dear rogue, the pretty fool dotes on me; my Lord Barbarin can do nothing with her; his piſtols and jewels ſhe cares not for. And tis a handſome thing: no Pomatum ere toucht her lips, or painted her cheeks, yet are they cherries and roſes; I am moſt happy to be what I am, and to have the love of ſuch a one as ſhe.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Good morrow Trappolin, how does my Love?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Firſt let us kiſs, and after I will tell,
For ever thine Flametta.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: O thanks my dear.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: The villain Trappolin has a handſome wench, and (which angers me) an honeſt one; I have ſpent many weeks about her, but could never do any good, ſhe will not neither for love or money; and ſee where they are a talking together.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Yonder is my Lord Barbarino.

My dear Flametta, I am your Honours ſervant; this free promiſe of thine, I can never enough thanke thee for—at your Lordſhips command. How happily ſhall we live together in marriage, both loving ſo well and truly? Your Honours humble ſlave. Let us kiſs agen—your poor vaſſal my Lord, thus will we ſpend our daies in theſe delights; ſo will we kiſs Flametta—I beſeech your Honour to pardon me: we nere will be a weary of our ſelves, if thou doſt ſigh, thy Trappolin will weep,—your Honour ſhall command me alwaies; and when thou ſingſt thy Trappolin will dance.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: And I am thine my honeſt Trappolin,
And ever will be conſtant unto thee.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I'le attend your Honour preſently.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: There's no man alive ſhall make me prove
Unfaithful unto thee, ſo much I love.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Your Lordſhip muſt pardon me a little,
I am ſomething buſie.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: My Trappolin ſhall not beſtow a kiſs,
But I will pay it him with uſury;
It is impoſſible for thee to be
More thy Flametta's then Flametta's thine.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I will come to your Honour preſently.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Pardon Sweetheart that now I muſt be gone,
My ſtay another time ſhall make amends:
A kiſs my dear, my lovely Trappolin;
With ſuch I ſhall be never ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Farewel my dear rogue; my Lord I come,
sp.p: Your Honour muſt pardon me, you ſaw how I was employ'd, I could not leave the poor fool, your Lordſhip ſees ſhe loves me, and proteſt her labour is not loſt: now if your Honour hath any thing to command me, I am ready Trappolino, your poor ſervant.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: You are a ſawcy peremptory villain,
And I have well perceiv'd your baſe demeanor;
Although I ſee the wench is yours, you ſhall
Repent the freedome of your evil language,
Be ſure you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Good morrow my Lord,
sp.p: Let him do his worſt I care not a ruſh for him; he would ha my wench, and I am glad I abus'd him, I ha made his Honour ſomething collerick, let him diſgeſt it how he will.

div.stage: Enter Lavinio the great Duke, Prudentia, Barbarin, Machavil and others.

sp.speaker: Lavin.
sp.l: The Tuſcane glory have we yet upheld,
And from the fierce aſſaults of enemies
Reſcued our cities, ſet them in a peace
As happy as the Gods did ere vouchſafe.
Sforza the Duke of Milain our old friend,
Who hath in all our wars ſtill ſent us aide,
Hath promiſed me the matchleſs Iſabella
His ſiſter for my wife; and ſeeing now
We have no more to do with enemies,
I will to Milain go and marry her,
And quickly unto Florence will return,
Where I will celebrate our nuptial
With that magnificence becomes our ſtate.
You, whom I ever have found faithful to me,
Lord Barbarino, and Lord Machivil,
To you I do commit the government
Of Tuſcany until I return;
And full commiſſion to do what you ſhall
See neceſſary for the good of Florence:
My dear Prudentia, the onely joy
Of our deceaſed Father, the laſt Duke,
Live happy, and enjoy thy own deſires,
Which I do know are vertuous all.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Moſt noble Sir, it is impoſſible
That I ſhould happy be, and you not preſent:
But I am unworthy to beſeech your ſtay;
Go and be fortunate in a worthy choice,
While I to heaven pray for your ſafe return.
Dear ſweet Prudentia, and alſo Lords,
Look well unto my priſoner Brunetto;
Yet let him want nothing but a free releaſe,
For ſure he is more then he ſeems to be.
I have been long about this journey; now
All things are ready, my Prudentia
Farewel; and ſiſter, be not melancholy,
For in few weeks I will return, and bring
A ſiſter home to keep thee company,
The beauteous Milanes.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: And may ſhe prove
According to your wiſhes, noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: And be a joy unto the Florentines.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: And be a happy mother, that there may
Not want an heir unto your Highneſs.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Our thanks;
Onward, tis time I were upon my way.

sp.speaker: Barba.
sp.l: Now will I be reveng;d of Trappolin,
Who hath ſo boldly to my face abus'd me;
I have authority to do't withall,
I'le make him to repent his ſawcineſs.
He's here, but I will do't as if by Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I can think of nothing but my pretty villain Flammetta; O 'tis a dear rogue, and ſhe ſaies ſhe loves me, and I know ſhe does: when I have married her I will betake me to the country, where we will live as jovial as the day is long.—

sp.speaker: Mat▪
sp.l: I'le fight for Florence while I have a vein
To hold my heart from falling unto death;
Nor ſhall the Longobardy Mantuaus
Ere win a Flag while I am in the field;
I'de make the Tuſcan Duke to know the man
Whom he hath truſted to conduct his troops,
Durſt but Gonzaga ever ſtir again.
Methinks there is no nobler thing on earth,
Then to ſee hills of bodies, lakes of blood:
No braver Muſick then the Martial Drum;
Nor Diapaſons ſweeter to the ear,
Then unto it the Warlike Trumpets make;
When I but hear this harmony, I could,
Full of delight, venter my ſingle perſon
Againſt an armed Troop. Away with peace,
It is the Canker and the bane of minds;
'Tis that which makes us to forget our ſelves,
And ſpend our lives in ſenſuality.
Then glorious war advance thy armed arm,
That ſoldiers may have waies to ſhew themſelves;
Wo'd Gothes and Vandals once again would come
Int' Italy, or Moors into our Spain,
That Mattemores might wear out his ſword
With hewing bones, and cleaving armed men:
Each thing doth to his centre fall, and I
Would unto mine, which is to fight or die.
Who art thou?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I!

sp.speaker: Matte.
sp.l: I you! what are you to good to be asked?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I am Trappolin.

sp.speaker: Matte.
sp.l: By that I know not, art thou a man of war?
Is Trappolin in any Captains roll?
I'ſt writ?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Yes (Seignior Captain) in the Parſons book,
The day thereof my baptiſme is ſet down.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And in that honour oft haſt thou ere fought
With Infidels, and ſlain a ſcore or two?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Not I, Heavens be prais'd, a ſcore or two ſaid you Captain? then ſhould I ſure never eſcape, for I promiſe you many an one is hang'd for killing of one.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Fie, what an ignorance is this! haſt thou a mind to become now a ſouldier?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Indeed, Seignior Captain, I cannot reſolve you as yet, I am about a wife, Ile ask her if ſhe will turn ſouldier too, and then if I like it ther's an end. But I pray you Captain what is a ſouldier?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: A ſouldier, Trappolin, is he that does
Venter his life a hundred times a day,
VVood in his countries, and his Princes cauſe
Stand canon ſhot, and wood of ſteeled pikes▪
VVood when his bodie's full of wounds all night,
Lie in the field and ſleep upon his helm.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Good Captain pardon me, neither I nor Flametta will be ſouldiers; heavens defend, venter my life ſo many times a day! there is more ſafety and gain in turning thief: I love my countrey and Prince well, but my ſelf better; 'tis good ſleeping in a whole skin, tis better lying with Flametta in a warm bed; marry I had thought a ſouldier had not been ſuch a fool.

How many of them might there be in Florence,
Sir Captain?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Thou coward, many hundreds.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: The Gods ſend them more wit, thats eene all that I can ſay: but I pray you Sir Captain, now I think ont' • perſwade my Father and mother, ſiſters and uncles, and aunts, and all the kin I have to turn ſouldiers, that they may be kil'd quickly and I be their heir; I ſwear Captain you ſhould loſe nothing by't, I would give you a good preſent for't.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Baſe coward.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Good Captain, what is the meaning of coward? I have often heard that word, and would fain know the true meaning of it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: A coward is a fellow baſe as thou,
One that doth ſpend his precious time in ſloth,
Cares not what alterations kingdomes have,
So he at home may welter in his pleaſures;
A fellow that had rather ſit all day
Drinking tobacco, and carouſing cups,
Then die his ſword in blood of enemies.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: VVhy then Captain, in faith I am a very coward; tis better by half then a ſouldier, I know there is far more pleaſure in a glaſs of good wine and a pipe of true Varines, then in bullets whizzing about ones ears, and pikes or halberts, or what you will abeating out ones teeth.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Thou dunghil wretch.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
Seignior Captain, be not angry, for I vow I mean earneſt, I ſhould never digeſt the ſouldiery
life, nor am I ſure wood Flametta, and the Gods help them that do.

sp.speaker: Matte.
sp.p: Thou earthen-minded ſlave, tis pity thou ſhouldeſt eat or drink that haſt no better thoughts,

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Not as long as I pay for't; what the Devil have I to do with your ſouldery Sir Captain? give me leave to be of my own mind, and a Coward; for i'me ſure no wiſe man but wood ſay as I do, let thoſe follow your wars that are aweary of their lives.

sp.speaker: Matte.
sp.p: Thou art as dunghil a minded Raſcal as ere I heard in my life; I would not for any thing thou waſt a Spaniard, thou wouldſt be a ſlander to the whole Nation. And Villain, I tell thee if thou wert one, I would kill thee; Mattemores would do it, and ſo I leave it.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Farewel my Sir Don, go hang your ſelf, what have I to do with your wars tro? for nothing would I venter to fight but Flametta, and for her I durſt not exceed about it fifty Cuffs, or about with a little pair of Cudgels at the moſt: I ſhould never endure to ſhoot off a Gun, not I, the very noiſe of it would make me endanger my Breeches,

Brunetto, honeſt Brunetto, how doſt do? be merry man, this time will have an end man, and till it come be as jovial as thou canſt, thou wouldſt ene a ble ••
thy ſelf to a ſeen how I vext the patience of my Lord Barbarin.

sp.speaker: Horat.
sp.p: You have not ſure.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Marry but I have, and to the purpoſe too.

sp.speaker: Horat.
sp.p: Then you are undone Trappolin.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Why man?

sp.speaker: Horat.
sp.p: The Duke has left him and the Lord Machavil governours till his return,

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: The Devil he has.

sp.speaker: Horat.
sp.p: Tis very true.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Troth then I am but little better I fear.
Thats he,
Lay hold on him.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Brunetto, I am und • n, thy Trappolin muſt to the Jayle, pray you my ſmall friends give me leave to ſpeake but one word, Remember me to my ſugar-candy Flametta.
Away with him.
To priſon with the ſaucy Rogue.

sp.speaker: Horat.
sp.l: I came to Mantoa to ayde the Duke
My Uncle gainſt his foes the Florentines,
Where hearing every man to praiſe the beauty
Of ſweet Prudentia, the report did win me;
Being taken in the wars, I was not ſad,
Becauſe I was to go where ſhe did live:
But ſeeing ſo many Princes all deſirous▪
To marry her, I knew the great Duke never
Would beſtow her on Savoyes ſecond Son.
And therefore yet I have concealed my ſelf;
Nor doth ſhe know I am Horatio:
For want of opportunity I yet
Could nere ſo much as ſigh within her hearing.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: The Lady Iſabella, by her picture,
May be ſuppoſed to be a matchleſs fair one;
Each feature of her face is wondrous good,
And her fine head of hair's a curious colour.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: In her we ſhall be happy all, for ſhe
The world reports hath equal to her forme
A noble and a vertuous mind; Whoſe that?

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: He is your brothers priſoner, called Brunetto,
That in the wars of Mantoa was took.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Tis a handſome man.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: And thought by all the Court a Gentleman
Of good deſcent, but he hath not diſcloſed
His parentage to any.

sp.speaker: Prude.
sp.l: Why doth he not?

sp.speaker: Hipol.
sp.l: That no man knows yet beſides himſelf.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: How melancholy he doth ſeem?

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: He hath good cauſe for it Madam:
Who can be merry in Captivity?

sp.speaker: Pruden.
sp.l: Tis true;
A Gentleman of good deſcent ſuppoſ'd,
I never ſaw a man of braver Carriage,
Nor one that pleas'd me better then he doth;
Aha!

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: Why ſigh you Madam?

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: To think of fortune; perhaps this priſoner
Is of a houſe as good as the Medices,
Hath lived before the wars of Mantua,
In all the happineſs you could deſire,
And now we ſee him thus.

sp.speaker: Hipol.
sp.l: Methinks I hear him ſigh.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: And ſo do I.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: He's gone.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: But with how ſad a gate?
Methinks I am not as I was before.
Hipolita.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Preethee go tune my Lute, I have a mind
To ſing a little, I ſhall forget to play
If I ſo ſeldome uſe it.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I go Madam.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: I have ſent her hence that I might ſearch my heart,
For ſure it is not as it lately was;
It is ſo full of thoughts, I cannot find
The free acceſs into it I had wont:
What ſhould the reaſon be, what have I don
To breed this alteration? nothing I,
Ere I came here I felt my ſelf as free
From this ſtrange—what it is I cannot tell,
The place is not bewitched ſure, nor have
I ſeen ought but this hapleſs priſoner.
'Alas poor Gentleman, (for in his looks
And in his carriage I can gueſs him ſuch)
How little to the fates art thou beholding
To let thee live a priſoner thus? how now!
What i'ſt I ſay, talk of Brunetto? Oh,
I am in Love, the Gods will have it ſo.

div.head: Scena tertia.
div.stage: Enter Barbarino, Machavil, Mattemores, and Officers leading Trappolin after them.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: This man, Lord Machavil, is one of thoſe
That doth in Florence nouriſh vice, he is
A pander, one that if he ſees a ſtranger,
Straight makes acquaintance with him, for what end
Your ſelf may gueſs; ſo he may gain thereby
He would betray our daughters, lead our ſons
To Brothels, vicious and full of rottenneſs.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I wonder how the Divel he came to know any thing that I did.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: This writing yeſternight was preſented to me:
Here you may ſee what enormities he is guilty of.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: His Lordſhip would ſhew himſelf a great hater of bawdery.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.p: Tis good we did examine him.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: And there is not ſuch a coward in Tuſcany; He's able to corrupt an army.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Seignior Captain, never fear it, for I nere mean to come into one.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Bring him before us.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
Ah that I durſt tell my Lords Excellence why
he deals thus with me, tis for a wench, and yet how eager he is againſt bawdery.

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.p: Forward Trappolin, go before their Excellencies.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Sirra, this paper doth not onely ſhew
You are a rogue, your looks declare you one,
Thou haſt as ill a face as ere I ſaw.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: And yet Flametta think'ſt as good as his,
I did not lie and if I ſaid a better.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Ere we come to his pandariſme, I'le examine him about other matters;
Sir, do you never uſe to carry piſtols about you?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Sometimes and pleaſe your Excellence I do.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Write down that Notarie.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: What does your Lordſhip mean, I did not ſteal them.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: I know well enough what I do; ſirra, you went to ſhoot ſome body.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Beſeech your Honour to take me along with you, I mean money.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.p: That's vain, then Notarie tear it out.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Do you nere carry other armes neither?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Many times my Lord.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Nota • ie down with it, he ſhall be talk'd with for that.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Your Honour is deceiv▪d agen, I mean onely armes upon ſeales, or ſcutchions from the Heralds.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: This is nothing Notarie, tear it out.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: A pimp I'me ſure he is.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Do you never carry no Love Letters, as from a Gentleman to a Lady, or a Gentlewoman to a Cavalier, or ſo?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: O very oft my Lord.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Do you ſo indeed? Notarie write it down.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Your Honour muſt underſtand me, Letters of Love, of friendſhip, as when a Lady writes unto her brother at Siena, a wife to her husband at Piſa, a ſon to his mother at ſuch a place, a father to his daughter married at ſuch a town, I am often hired, and carry them to the Poſt.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Notarie, you muſt tear out this too.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: But ſirra, to come nearer to the matter,
Do you not keep intelligence with Whores?
Have you nere plaid the Ruffian? by your means
Hath no man been provided of a lodging?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: This I have no excuſe for, the whole city knowes me a pimp.
And that it is very nigh my living.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: What ſay you ſirra?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: My Lords, I am but a poor fellow, and muſt live.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: By Bawdery?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Tis but a friends part.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: A wicked ones, Notarie down with this at large.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Alas my Lord, what hurt is it, if I help a Gentleman to a ſound wench, where is there any fault? good your Honours, conſider me, think not I am a man alone in this buſineſs, that many others live by it as well as I.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What an impudency is this?
Not onely to do ill, but to defend it,
Is a tranſgreſſion exceeds forgiveneſs.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Good my Lord take pity on me, wel a day what ſhould I do!
I have not onely done a favour in it for my ſelf, but alſo a courteſie for many a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.p: Do not teare out that, Notarie.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Beſeech your Honours let him tear't out.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: What ſhall we do with this villain?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Why let's hang him and ther's an end of him.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: That's true I faith, conſider my Lords, that never man was put to death for ſuch a matter, but rather that they have been beloved, and well paid by noble men and cavalieres.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.p: Had we not beſt to condemn him to the Gallies? or lets baniſh hm.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: I that's the beſt.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Beſeech your Honours pity me.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: After to morrow, Trappolin, if thou be'ſt ſeen in Florence thou ſhalt die, be hang'd; we baniſh thee for term of life, therefore prepare againſt to morrow to be gone.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Pray your Honours.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Notarie, write down he's baniſh't.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: You rogue, it is irrevocable, and therefore make you ready.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
I think I am the firſt man that ever was baniſh't for ſuch a matter; were all of my profeſsion in
the City ſerved ſo, I think we ſhould make an Army Royal of us.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: This matter is concluded, Trappolin;
Go ſeek your fortune. My Lord Machavil;
We may depart.

sp.speaker: Matte.
sp.l: Thou man of durt, hadſt thou a Souldier been,
This baniſhment had never been pronounc'd.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: But Sir Captain, I fear I ſhould have been kil'd, which is worſe.

sp.speaker: Matte.
sp.l: If for thy Country, t' had been a noble death.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I had rather live Cap. then die nobly.

sp.speaker: Matte.
sp.l: Thou man compos'd of ſand, in vain I ſpend
My breath to talk with ſuch a ſlave as thou;
Go and be hang'd, for • o thou do doſt deſerve,
And might I judge thee, it ſhould be thy end.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Thou brazen-headed Coxcomb, may'ſt thou go to the divel with a Drum before thee; I had as leeve be baniſh't out of my Country and walk in peace, as be out on't in the wars.
Brunetto, O Brunetto, I muſt leave thee, I muſt be gone Man to morrow, farewell Florence.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Why, whats the matter Trappolin?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Why, I have baniſh't the Lord Barberino, and the Lord Machavil.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: How! you baniſh't them?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
They have baniſhed me, or I them, 'tis all one, I muſt be gone, and the divel a bit a mony I have: ſhall I help thee to a Wench Brunetto? Or if thou
haſt no mind to one, know'ſt thou any body that has? I'de fain be earning a little mony.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I wiſh thee well, live honeſt Trappolin,
And ſo thou ſhalt be ſure to proſper better;
This Ring I give thee, ſell it, and the mony
Spend to maintain thee.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Honeſt Brunetto, faith
An ere I can I will requite thee fully;
Farewell, I muſt alſo take my leave
Of my Flametta▪ we ſhall cry together
Like unto School Boys that are to be whipt.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Alas poor ſimple Trappolin, I pity
Thy fortune, yet 'tis better far then mine;
Of all mankind I am moſt miſerable,
And lead a life would make a ſoul prove mortal,
Yet do I not repine: Moſt dear Prudentia,
I never can endure enough for thee,
So that at laſt I may attain my wiſhes:
There's not a grief mankind did ever ſuffer▪
Nor pain, I would not paſs to make thee mine;
Thou art the Centre of my wiſhes, all
Horatio's thoughts upon thy beauty fall.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: O Heavens, be merciful, and if I tell
Him I am his, let him ſay he is mine▪
I have a fire within my breaſt muſt out,
Longer I cannot hide it, if he now
Do's not wooe me, I ſhall ſolicite him.
How ſad a pace he walks? how melancholy
Do's he look? Love compels us unto things
In others we would ſcorn; I'le ſpeak unto him,
Becauſe I fear he dares not unto me.
Brunetto.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Divineſt Lady.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: I thought a Gentleman (for ſo I gueſs you)
Could have endured affliction better far,
That in the wars durſt venter ſo his perſon.
