sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And he be grown wiſe again, Heavens be praiſed.
It is a certain truth your Highneſs ſpeaks,
That if your ſiſter ſhould beſtow her ſelf
(Being a Princeſſe meriting ſo much
For her unequal'd beauty, and her vertues)
Upon a man ſuch as you pleaſ'd to mention,
It would be a great weakneſs in her; but you
Your ſelf I heard (moſt excellent Sir)
To call Brunetto Prince Horatio,
The ſecond Sonne unto the Duke of Savoy.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: How, I call him ſo! truth Captain you
Have heard theſe things which I did never ſay.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You never heard him call Brunetto ſo.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Never, this is the firſt time I ever heard of it.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: My wonder is ſo great, I do want words
VVhereby to give it vent; I ſee that all
My ſubjects being diſtracted think me mad.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And more, ſo pleaſe your Highneſs, you did ſend
Brunetto, whom you Prince Horatio called,
Unto your ſiſter, to bid her prepare
Her ſelf; for you within a day or two
Would ſee them married.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Enough,
Captain, I ſwear unto you by my Dukedome,
That rather I would ſend Brunetto (though
He were the Duke of Savoys ſecond ſon)
To have his head ſtruck off, then on that meſſage
You ſay I did.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: He doth remember nothing.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: If the Duke be come to his right ſences again,
I beſeech the Gods keep him ſo.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Beſeech your Highneſs look, let your own eyes
Be witneſs of their mutual affection;
Behold the Princeſs your ſiſter and Brunetto:
Let us withdraw where we may ſtand unſeen,
And you ſhall hear them talk what I have ſaid.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Dear Lady, you have raiſed me to a fortune
So high, that when I look upon my ſelf
I am amaz'd, and wonder at your goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Moſt noble Prince, let my unfeigned love
Excuſe the weak expreſſions of my tongue;
I'm glad my Brother bears ſo noble a mind,
As to be willing to unite our bodies
As we have done our hearts.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Not only willing, divine Prudentia,
But earneſt for us; he doth ſeem to grieve
That two ſuch faithful lovers as we are
Should live ſo long a ſunder.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: It is a worthy nature in him.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I can contain my ſelf no longer: though this
Be out of madneſs done I will not ſuffer it.
Siſter!

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Live long moſt worthy Brother happily.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: So ſhould I wiſh for you, bore you a mind
Deſerv'd your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: What mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Good Heavens be kind, and do not now undo
What you have almoſt brought unto perfection;
I fear his m adneſs that once favoured me;
Hath chang'd his mind to my undoing.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I will but ſpend few words; are you a Son
Of the Duke of Savoys?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Your Highneſs knowes I am his ſecond.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Whether
You are or no I care not; and if you be,
My ſiſter once deſerv'd a better husband,
And ſhe ſhall rather in a Monaſtery
Spend all her future dayes then be your wife:
And be you what you will Sir, I will ſhew you
That you have wronged me, and I do not fear
The Duke of Savoy if he be your father.
Puchanello, Puchanello come hither.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I like this.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: He's wonderfully diſtracted—moſt worthy Brother,
Be not ſo much unmerciful.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Peace Prudentia, I never thought
You had ſo weak a reaſon.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: He's mad to my undoing; gracious Gods,
Soon make him leave this humour.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I hope he's come unto himſelf.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Sirra, convey Brunetto into priſon,
Lock him up cloſe.

sp.speaker: Puc.
sp.l: Here's do and undo—Will our Duke nere be in his
Right ſences again?

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: My dear Horatio, love me ſtill, for I
Unto thee will be conſtant though I die.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Though I be tortured unto death my Dear.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I know not what to think of theſe alterations.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Thus (but the heavens aſſiſt) I hope to bring
Int' order from confuſion every thing.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: THe Duke is come home, and therefore my hardeſt part is behind; Father Conjurer and you be not my friend now I am undone; Eo, Meo, and Areo ſit you all cloſe and loſe not a jot of your vertue: happen what will as ſoon as I meet him his Highneſs, I will try the vertue of my powder on him, let him take it how he pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Here is my brother, I will try him, perhaps
He may have chang'd his ſullen humor now,
And ſet the Prince Horatio at liberty.
Moſt excellent noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: My dear ſiſter, how doſt thou do? why look you ſo ſad, ha you got the green ſickneſs to night with lying alone? and you have I will take an order for your cure very ſhortly, and to your liking too, I'le have you married within theſe two days at the furtheſt.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Married Sir! unto whom?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Unto my friend your lover, Prince Horatio▪

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: I am glad of this: Alas Sir, why then have you
Made him a cloſe unhappy priſoner?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I ſee the Duke hath met with him:
You do deceive your ſelf Lady ſiſter, indeed
You do▪ put up my friend in priſon? heaven defend.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Sir, pardon me for ſpeaking truth, I heard
When you commanded it.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Siſter mine, if I did I was drunk, and now I am ſober I will let him out. Sirra Pucchanello, ſo ho.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: May he continue always in this vein
Of kindneſs; thus his madneſs is not grievous.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Madam ſiſter, I am very ſorry I was ſuch a beaſt as in my drink to commit ſuch a fault; I pray you forgive me.

sp.speaker: Pucch.
sp.l: What is your Highneſs will?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: It is that you ſet Prince Horatio at liberty, and ſend him hither preſently.

sp.speaker: Pucch.
sp.l: I wonder—moſt willingly.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: You are a gracious Prince, and the high Gods
Will recompence your pity unto lovers.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: What a Swine was I do ſuch a thing! I am aſhamed as often as I think on't, I ſhall be aſhamed to look on my friend; ſiſter, you muſt pray him to forgive me.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Sir, trouble not your ſelf, and be aſſur'd,
Unleſs you part us, you can never do
Offence either unto the Prince or me.

sp.speaker: Hora,
sp.p: It ſeems his mind is changed, the heavens be praiſed.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Prince Horatio, an you do not forgive me my locking of you in priſon, I ſhall never be merry again; I did it when I was drunk, and my ſiſter knows that as ſoon as ſhe told me on't, I ſent for you; I pray you therefore forgive me good Prince Horatio.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Moſt excellent Sir, I was a man unworthy
Of this ſweet Ladies love, did I not freely.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I thank you i'faith Prince Horatio with all my heart I ſwear unto you, here take you my ſiſter, take her by the hand, lead her whether you will, and do what you will unto her with her conſent: I am very ſorry I parted you ſo long; I know Lovers would be private, though they do nothing but talk, therefore I will not hinder you: fare you well both my Princely friend and Lady ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: The Gods preſerve you.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: And reward your goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Thus what the Duke doth I will undo—ſuch excuſes will ſerve my turn well enough.
Here are my Lord baniſhers, it ſeems the Duke hath ſet them at liberty, but in they go again as ſure as the cloaks on their backs.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: May the good angels that attend upon
Princes on earth, defend your Highneſs always
From every offenſive thing.

sp.speaker: Macc.
sp.l: And may you live
A long and happy life, enlarge your ſtate,
Excel in fame the firſt great Duke.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Your good wiſhes I like, but credit me my Lord Baniſhers, neither of you. Who let you out of priſon?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He's mad as ere he was—your Highneſs Sir.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: You lye Sir: Pucchanello come hither quickly.

sp.speaker: Macc.
sp.l: Heavens be merciful, we muſt in again I ſee.
He do's and undo's, and remembers nothing.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Sirra Rogue, why did you ſet theſe two at liberty?

sp.speaker: Pucc.
sp.l: Your Highneſs did command it.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: If our Duke muſt be mad, the Gods grant him
That which he had the laſt.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: You ill-fac'd raſcal you lie.

sp.speaker: Pucc.
sp.l: Beſeech your Highneſs remember your ſelf, it
Was at your command.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: It may be ſo, but I am ſure I was drunk then, and now I am ſober they ſhall in again; therefore take them with you, be gone I ſay.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: There is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Macc.
sp.p: Good gods pitty Florence.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Eo, Meo, and Areo, thanks i'faith▪ yet I am ſuppos'd the Duke, Father Conjurer, by thy Art I am ſuppos'd a Prince; ſtick to me ſtill and be my friend.
Here is the Dutcheſs! Eo, Meo, and Areo, be true to me, and I'le have a kiſs or two at the leaſt.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.l: Sir you are fortunately met.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Who are you Lady Madam?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.l: Do you not know Sir?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I'de have you tell me.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.l: I never knew him ſo before, I am your Wife.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I'me glad on't I promiſe you, come and kiſs me then.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.l: You are wondrous merrily diſpoſed.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Madam Dutcheſs I am ſomething jovial indeed, I have been a drinking Montefiaſcone very hard, kiſs me again my dear Lady wife.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.l: He's drunk.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: You are a handſome woman I promiſe you: prethee tell me my Lady Dutcheſs, am I a proper handſome fellow?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.l: Do not jeſt with me Sir, you know you are
Him whom above the world I do eſteem.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Well ſaid my Ladie wife.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.l: I nere ſaw him ſo diſtempered before.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Have you nothing yet in your belly?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.l: You know I am with child Sir.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Faith but I do not, for your belly ſwells not.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.l: I am full of wonder.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
Lady wife get you in, I am halfe drunk, and now am unfit for you, but give me a kiſs or two
before,—Madam Dutcheſs fare you wel.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: I had thought he had not been addicted to
A vice ſo loathſome as drunkenneſs.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Yet all happens very well; proteſt the Dutcheſs is a gallant woman, I almoſt like her as well as Flametta; I could lie with her and I woo'd, but I am half honeſt, and will not wrong the Duke nor Flametta. Why is not my wench as good as ſhe? wherein do they differ, but onely in clothes? Flametta's a woman as right as ſhe, and perhaps naked as handſome: what good in the night do jewels and fine clothes to a woman when ſhe hath them not on? beſworn I am very merry; Eo Meo and Areo are brave tame Devils, and my Father Conjurer an excellent learned fellow.

l.hi: Trivigi tripes, and a Venice wench in bed.

lg.l: YE glorious Plannets that do rightly guide
The giddy ſhips upon the Ocean waves,
If ſome of your malignant influences
Have rais'd this madneſs in my ſubjects heads,
Let ſome of your benigne influences,
Again reſtore them to their former ſences:
Thoſe Florentines whom all their enemies
Could not impeach, could not withſtand in armes,
Suffer not, you immortal powers divine,
Thus to be ruin'd, by diſtraction.

sp.stage: Machavil and Barbarino appear in priſon.
sp.p: I am aſtoniſhed, O Heavens, I know not what to think!
Puchanello, Puchanello, let me out the two Lords, and ſend them to me preſently, I'le talk unto um here at large.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: His ill fit's off.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: The goods be praiſed.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I do not think that ſince the infancy
And firſt creation of the world, a madneſs
Peſtiferous and equal unto this
Was ever known; good Heavens reveal (and ſoon)
The cauſe, that I may do my beſt to help it.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Long may this fit continue.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: If it hold alwaies, ſure he's in's wits agen.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I wonder, Lords, and juſtly, that you whom I have known to have the nobleſt judgements, ſhould thus become diſtracted; you in your fits of frenzie run to priſon of your ſelves,
And think I ſent you.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Moſt royal Sir, we grieve to ſee theſe daies;
You did command us thither.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Your Highneſs ſelf.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: You are both deceiv'd; to do ſuch idle errours,
And lay the blame on me doth more amaze me.
Puchanello how came theſe in priſon?

sp.speaker: Puc.
sp.l: So pleaſe your Highneſs, you were angry with them
And did commit them.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I commit them?
That thou art mad is not ſo great a wonder;
I tell you both with ſorrow, witneſs heaven,
You are ſtrangely bereav'd of your reaſon.
Well, go ye in, and pray unto the Gods
That they hereafter would be kind unto you
And keep you from relapſe.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Heavens bleſs your Highneſs.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And be unto you a perpetual guard.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Famine, plague, war, the ruinous inſtruments
Wherewith the incenſed dieties do puniſh
Weak mankind for miſdeeds, had they all fallen
Upon this city, it had been a thing
To be lamented but not wondred at.
O my dear Iſabella! I have brought thee
From Milain flouriſhing in all delights,
Into a city full of men diſtracted.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: He is not ſober yet. Go in and ſleep Sir,
You do not well thus to bewray your weakneſs
Unto the publick view.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: My wife and all! O heavens!

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.l: What ſay you Sir?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: My Iſabella, thou haſt cauſe to curſe me
For bringing thee into a place infected:
The aire is ſure peſtiferous, and I wonder
Now how I have eſcaped.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Good Sir, I pray you ſleep.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Wherefore my Iſabella?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Why you have drunk too much.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Madneſs unmatch'd!
Dear Iſabella, withdraw thy ſelf into
Thy chamber, I will preſently come to thee,
There we will pray unto the angry Gods
That they would from's remove this heavy ill.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: I will obey you Sir to get you home;
Good Gods nere let him thus offend again.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: What have I done ſo much offenſive to
The ſupreme powers, that they ſhould puniſh me
Not onely with the madneſs of my ſubjects,
But the diſtraction of my wife and ſiſter!
What do I ſee? they do embrace and kiſs:
My ſiſters madneſs will undo her, how
He came at liberty I marvel much;
sp.p: Whom I would have to lie in priſon, walke in freedome, and whom I would have in freedome run of themſelves to priſon.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Moſt noble Brother.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Siſter, I grieve to ſee thee thus.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Excellent Prince!

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Sure the good Angels that had wont to guard
The Medices in all their actions,
Have for the horrid ſins of Florence left us,
And fled to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: His mind again is altered.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Dear brother, do not frown and look ſo angry.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Peace ſister, I'me aſham'd to hear you ſpeak,
Each word you ſay is poyſon in my eares.

sp.speaker: Puchanello,
sp.l: Jailor.

sp.speaker: Puc.
sp.l: I come.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: What mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I muſt again to priſon, fickle fortune,
How ſoon a happy man thou makeſt wretched▪

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Sirra, why did you ſet this man Brunetto,
Or this Horatio (I know not what to call him,)
At liberty?

sp.speaker: Puc.
sp.l: Will he nere be wiſe! your Highneſs bade me.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I! Bethink you, and anſwer truly.

sp.speaker: Puc.
sp.l: Your Highneſs knowes I durſt not for my life
Ha don't without your licence.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Sweet Brother.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Silence would become you better far.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Life of my heart, do not diſturb your ſelf,
I am unworthy you ſhould ſpeak for me.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Sirra, take him again, and look to him better then you have; your madneſs ſhall not excuſe you, if once more you ſerve me thus.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I muſt be patient: good Heavens, ſoone alter this ſullen fit into his former kindneſs:
sp.l: Farewel my ſweet Prudentia.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: I wonder Brother, what pleaſure you take
In croſſing me after this ſort.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: It is in vain to anſwer frantick people.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: I, I am mad, 'tis your perverſneſs makes me.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: YEt I cannot meet with the Duke, I long to ſee him look like me, I would fain powder his Highneſs. Eo, Meo and Areo, I thank you faith, my hat, my glaſs, and cloke; honeſt Father Conjurer, I will love thee while I live.
Hel's broke looſe again, I do what the Duke undoes, and he undoes what I do.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Long live your Highneſs.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Amen.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And happily.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Amen I ſay; but how my ſmall friends came you hither? I thought you had been under lock & key.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I fear he's ill as ere he was.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Sirra Puchanello, ſo ho, ſo ho! come hither you rogue.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: We muſt in again.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Good Gods, will this frenzie never leave him!

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
Goodman durty-face, why did you not keep
me theſe in priſon till I bid you let them out?

sp.speaker: Puc.
sp.l: So pleaſe your Highneſs ſo I did.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Dare you lie ſo boldly? you take me for a Doctor, Gracian of Franckolin I warrant you, or a fool in a play, you'r ſo ſawcy with me.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Good Gods!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Was ever heard the like?

sp.speaker: Puc.
sp.l: Beſeech your Highneſs to remember your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Now I bethink my ſelf, perhaps I might do it when I was drunk; if I did bid you give them their liberty it was when I was fox't, and now I am ſober lay them up agin; walk my good Lord Baniſhers, your Honours know the way.

sp.speaker: Puc.
sp.l: Will this humour never leave him?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: We muſt endure it.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: There is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: My Lord Priſoners get you gone, I am an hungry and cannot ſtand to hear any ſupplication.

sp.speaker: Puc.
sp.l: You muſt obey my Lords.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Yet all goes well, all goes exceeding well;
My wil's obey'd, I am ſuppos'd the Duke;
My hat my glaſs and cloak retain their force,
And Father Conjurer does not forſake me.

div.head: Scena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Mattemoros the Spaniſh Captain ſolus.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: THough horrid War, thou bear'ſt a bloody ſword,
And marcheſt o're the world in dreadful arms;
Though fearful mankind on their humble knees,
Beſeech the Gods to keep thee from their homes,
Yet art thou (when trick'd up in diſmall robes,
Preſaging death and ruine to a State)
More lovely to a valiant ſouldiers eyes,
Then are the pleaſures of a wanton Court.
And ſure if our great Duke Lavinio
Had been i'th field expecting of a foe,
He nere had been diſtracted as he is:
'Tis peace that doth bewitch us from our ſelves,
Fills moſt Heroick hearts with amorous toyes,
But for Hipolita's ſake I muſt not ſpeak
Any thing ill of Love; Love I muſt ſay
Is good, but war leads the more noble way.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: How do you Captain?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I am your Highneſs creature.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Saw you not lately Barbar▪ or Maccha?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Where are they?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Your Highneſs knows in priſon.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: O heavens, in priſon again! Good gods, when will you remove this frenzy from the Florentines?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I ſee there is little hope on him.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Why are they in priſon?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Becauſe your Highneſs did command.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Never, Captain, I never did command it; go and bid Pucchanello let them out.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Sir, he dares not at my bidding.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Here take my Ring and do't.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: One humor in the morning, and another in the afternoon, will it never be better?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Wo'd I did know what hainous ſin it is
I have commited that is ſo offenſive
Unto the Gods to cauſe this puniſhment,
That I might ſue unto them for forgiveneſs,
And they be reconcil'd and pitty Florence.
I'm f • ll, and full of wonder; perhaps ſome fiend,
Permitted by the heavens, aſſume's my ſhape,
And what I do undoth; was ever known
Such a diſtraction in the world before?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: At laſt I have found him.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: This the Impoſtor is that hath deceiv'd
The eyes of all, it can be nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
I vow and ſwear I am ſomething afraid, but
will be bold; Eo, Meo and Areo, ſit cloſe, come out powder, come out, father Conjurer I rely on your powder;
Take that for my ſake.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: What rudeneſs is this?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I have don't i'faith, Trap. I have repealed thee for Flametta's ſake.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: How is this?
If thou art a fiend, the gracious heavens be kind,
And give a period to thy wild proceedings;
But if thou art a Conjurer, I'le have thee
Burnt for thy Magick, as thou doſt deſerve.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Trappolin talk wiſely.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Why doſt thou call me ſo?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Aha! A man forget himſelf ſo! art thou not he?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am the Duke.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Beware of treaſon; do you know your own face if you ſee't? look here; what ſay you now?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am bewich't, thou art a Conjurer,
And haſt transformed me to a baniſh't Rogue.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: For Flametta's ſake I pardon thee this language, but learn to ſpeak better leſt you walk again.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Heaven, earth and hell, have all agreed together
To load me with a plague unknown before
Unto the world: The heavens have given conſent
Unto my miſery, hell hath plotted it,
And the deceived earth believes me mad,
And now will take me for a baniſh't Rogue.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: O joy above expreſſion! behold
My Trap. is come; Love, welcome home;
Thou art beholding unto me (my Dear)
'Twas I that won the Duke for thy repeal.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am amazed.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Give me a hundred kiſſes; let us ſpend
An hour in kiſſing, afterwards we'l talk.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Have you forgotten me ſo ſoon? I am
Thy true Flametta (lovely Trap.)

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Be gone I ſay.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Doſt thou reward me thus for all the pains
I've took to get thee home again?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Leave me
Thou impudent whore, or I will kick thee hence.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: O faithleſs men! Women, by me take heed
You give no truſt unto this perjur'd ſex.
Have I all thy long baniſhment been true,
Refuſed Lord Barbarino with all his gifts;
And am I ſlighted thus? I will complain
Unto his Highneſs of thee.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Have you don't?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Have you let the Lords at liberty?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: What's that to thee?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Give me my Ring.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: He has heard the Duke ſent me with his Ring, and this impudent Rogue dares think to get it. Sirra, is it not enough to be a Coward and a Pander, but you wo'd be a thief too?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am bewitched.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: I fear my Trappolin is turned mad man.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Suffer not this ye Gods.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I have ſet the Lords Barbarino and Macc. at liberty according to your Highneſs order; and here is your Ring again.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Better and better—I ma • le where the Prince Horatio is.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: He forgets every thing, he's in priſon.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Sure he is not.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: How this Impoſtor divel acts me!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Your Highneſs did commit him.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Fie upon't, what things do I do in my drink? here take my Ring, go and ſet him out, and come hither with him preſently.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am the Duke, and will be obey'd,
Go not upon your life, he ſhall lye there.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Sure my Trappolin's run mad for grief in his baniſhment.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Peace (frantique) peace, do not diſturb his Highneſs.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Regard not mad men, go.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'm gone.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Thou traitor.

sp.speaker: Fam.
sp.p: Dear Trappolin be ſilent, regard my tears, thou wilt undo thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Maiden and your Sweet-heart continue thus, I'le have him ſent abroad again.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Sweet Trappolin for my ſake hold thy tongue▪

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I rage in vain, good heavens be merciful.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Dear brother pity me, regard my ſorrow,
Releaſe the Prince Horatio, and no longer
Separate their bodies whoſe hearts the Gods have joyned.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Siſter, have patience a little, a very little, Prince Horatio will be here preſently, and Ile make an end with you.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Prudentia, art thou not aſham'd?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: What ſawcines is this▪
sp.p: Moſt worthy noble Brother all my heart is full o • thanks for you: wood Ide a tongue could utter them.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Your Highneſs ring.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Tis well: Captain, Siſter, and Prince Horatio,
Here take my ſignet, by the warrant of it, go
And get you married,

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Our humble thanks.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I do want patience.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Tis beſt to do it while he's in's good humor:
Are you content Sweet Princeſſe?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: With all my ſoul I go.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Siſter, ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Peace leſt you be ſoundly puniſht Sirra.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Good Trappolin be quiet.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am the Duke, I am Lavinio;
This is a fiend of hell or an Impoſtor.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Will your Highneſs ſuffer this?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I pity him, he knows not what he ſaies.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am bewitched.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I am ſure thou art diſtracted.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: A done you had beſt.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Thou enemy unto our happineſs,
Know the Gods will relent; in time be wiſe.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: There is no remedy, he muſt go to Puchanello: ſo ho, Pachanello, ſo ho.

sp.speaker: Puch.
sp.l: I come.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: There could come no better of it, beſeech your Highneſs pardon him, he's diſtracted.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: You are all diſtracted, all bewitched.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Sirra take Trap. and lock him up ſafe.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: You'd take no warning.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: O Florence, how I pity thy decay.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Puchanello take him, and be gone.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: You of the Guard ſee him laid ſafely up.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I will not go.

sp.speaker: Puch.
sp.l: We then might force you.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Alas poor Flametta! Thy Trappolin cares not for thee, I beſeech the Gods to give him his right ſences again.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Come Captain.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I attend your Highneſs.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: The ſtrange diſtraction of our Duke will give
Sufficient matter unto Chronicles
To make whole volumes of him.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Yet he believes himſelf right in his ſences
And we out of our wits think him mad.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Wood I had been born to a mean eſtate,
So in't I might have lived happily.
The greater honours that men have, the greater
Their troubles are; the begger that hath nothing
Lives a more quiet life then Monarchs do.
Lord Barbarino▪ and Lord Machavil,
Get me releas'd, I am the Duke Lavinio,
Bewitched as you are by an Impoſtor.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Go Trappolin and ſleep: we have heard al l,
Thou art run mad.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Go ſleep poor Trappolin.

sp.speaker: Lavin.
sp.l: Be kind good Gods, pity our miſeries.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Leave talking and go ſleep.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: His Highneſs.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: How fares our noble maſter?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I have not been ſober a day together this good while; Eo Meo and Areo have made me fox't, but now I will leave it.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Who are they?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: It's in vain to lay them up any more, I having had ſport enough with them. Trappolin whom you baniſht is come home ſtark mad.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And raves moſt ſtrangly in priſon.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Here is his Highneſs, I will not leave him till
He doth releaſe from priſon Trappolin.
Moſt excellent Sir, perfect your noble kindneſs;
Give liberty unto poor Trappolin.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: With all my heart I would, wood he be quiet.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Alas he is diſtracted, and doth not know
sp.p: VVhat he ſayes; and therefore why ſhould you regard him?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: VVell, fair maid, for thy ſake that loveſt him ſo he ſhal come out. Puchanello ſo ho! come hither.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He will do any thing, and undo any thing.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Sure there was never ſuch a Duke i'th world.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: VVelcome Siſter and Brother (I hope I may ſay,) are you married? are you content? tell me if any thing remains that I can do for you, ſpeak it, for I am ready, the Duke
Your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Moſt worthy brother, you have perfected our joyes, for we are married.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: I am very glad Lady ſiſter that you are ſo.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Here is your Highneſs ring.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: You Sirra of chains and keyes ſet me Trappolin at liberty preſently, and ſend him hither.

sp.speaker: Puc.
sp.p: VVill he never be wiſe? I wood he wood make another Jaylor, I am weary of the place, I can never be at quiet for putting in and ſetting out.

sp.speaker: Flam
sp.l: The Heavens reward your goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Brother and Prince Horatio, I am ſomething given to be drunk, Eo, Meo and Areo are good fellows: but I pray you pardon me.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Sir, you wrong your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: My friend, and Prince Horatio, I'le nere wrong my ſelf I warrant you; but you I have, and my ſiſter Prudentia: but it was when I was fox't, and I will never be ſo again.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I am glad he will once let us be quiet.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: I ſhould be very glad if he would continue it.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Ho now Seignior Captain▪ ha you got a ſweetheart?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: A fair Miſtreſs ſo pleaſe your Highneſs.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I ſee, my Don at Armes, when you cannot follow the wars of the field, you will of the bed.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Prethee my Trappolin, now hold thy tongue.
Be wiſe ſweet Love.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Leave me thou frantick fool.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: For Flametta's ſake I have given you your liberty, uſe it well.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: O Heavens, endure not this impoſtor thus
With his enchantments to bewitch our eyes.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Will he ſuffer him?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Perhaps one mad man wil pity another.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Ye Florentines, I am Lavinio,
I am the Tuskan Duke, this an enchanter,
That by his magick Art has raiſed all
Theſe ſtrange chimeraes in my Court.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Your Highneſs is too patient, it were more fit he rav'd in Priſon.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Sweet Trappolin be rul'd.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Hold your tongue I ſay.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Poor Trappolin, art thou diſtracted too?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: You Lords of Florence, wiſe Machavil, and
You Lord Barbarino, will you never come
Out of this frenzie? Valiant Mattemores,
I am the Duke, I am Lavinio:
This whom you do ſuppoſe is me, is ſome
Helliſh Magician that hath bewitched us all.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: He will not be rul'd: Puchanello take him again▪

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Beſeech your Highneſs: Trappolin, come away.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Was ever ſeen the like?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Ah my poor ſubjects! how I pity you,
That muſt obey the monſtrous wickedneſs
Of one that works by Necromantick means,
And is forſaken by the bleſſed Gods!

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Yon's Father Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What new accident is this!

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I hope he'l do no hurt.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: What will the event be (marle?)

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: What old Long-beard's this?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: A word with you,
Will you, if I clear every thing,
Pardon what's paſt?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Do you know me then?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: You are the Duke.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Father Conjurer, do no hurt, and I'le give you a hundred piſtols to buy you ſallets and oile it'h wood.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I'le talk with you even now;
Will you promiſe me?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I ſwear by all the honours of my ſtate,
By both my Dukedomes, Florence and Sienna,
I will forgive what ever's paſt.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Him and all?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Him and all.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Good Father Conjurer, remember your ſon.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: What will come of this?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Be not affrighted.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Never, not I.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: What ere you ſee,
Fear not, nothing ſhall hurt you.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: This is a Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Sweet Captain ſtand cloſe by me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What ſtrange events are theſe!

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Eo, Meo, and Areo, appear.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I am undone I fear.
sp.p: Father Conjurer, remember your ſon, I'le give you two hundred piſtols.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Appear I ſay.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Alas!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: Oh me!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Be bold, I am here Hipolita.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Go take the hat, the glaſs, and cloke from him.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Ah me! Ah me! here, here, here, here, come not too near me.
Eo, Meo, and Areo, farewel all on you; Father Conjurer has undone me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Trappolin.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Two Trappolins.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: I know not which is mine.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Attend a while.
Thus with the waſte of this enchanted wand
I do releaſe your Highneſs.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: The Duke.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Wonders.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: You have engaged your word, y'ave pardon'd all, me who have done and undone every thing, and him, and every body.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I have.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: The Heavens be prais'd; long live your Highneſs.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Long live the Duke.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I'le perfect every thing;
Brave Prince Horatio, your elder Brother,
Prince Filberto is dead. Sir, you cannot,
With reaſon diſlike this match, they are
Married, and your conſent doth perfect it.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Now I am aſſured he is a Turin Prince▪
Heir to the Dukedome of Savoy, I am glad
They are eſpouſed: ſiſter I wiſh you joy;
Sir, I intreat forgiveneſs for what's paſt.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: All's forgotten.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Thanks gracious Heavens.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I'le have your wedding ſolemnized with ſtate.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I am glad this Gordian knot's untied.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I ſhall be hang'd Father Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: The Duke hath pardoned you and me all.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Then let Eo, Meo, and Areo go to the Divel from whence they came. Flametta, I am thine.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Ah my dear Trappolin!

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Here is your Highneſs ring.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: From henceforth I abjure my wicked art.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I for thy love to me will ſend thee into
Piemondt, and give thee an Earldome in Vercelly.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: The Heavens reward you: you know I alwaies made much of your Highneſs Majeſty. Fla thou ſhalt be a Counteſs.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Son Trappolin, I am thy natural father, twenty years ſince baniſht ten years from Florence: through my misfortune I have ſerved the Turk in his Gallies.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: By your leave Father you have ſerved the Divel too I'me ſure: for you are one of the beſt Conjurers in the world. Welcome unto the Court, your ſon of Honour, and to Flametta's Earlſhip: will your Honours forgive me too?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: For the Princes ſake I do.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I thank you both: now all's well agen, henceforth I will live honeſtly and be the Divels Butcher no longer.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: My Iſabella welcome; every thing
That did moleſt our happineſs in Florence
Is took away, now we will ſpend our time
In Courtly joyes; our famous Tuskan Poets
Shall ſtudy amorous Comedies and Masks,
To entertain my beaute ous Millaneſs:
I have a ſtory full of ridiculous wonders,
Within to tell thee at our better leiſure.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: The weaker ſide muſt yield unto the ſtronger,
And Trappolin's ſuppos'd a Prince no longer.

lg.l: LAdies and Gentlemen, you that now may
Approve (or if you pleaſe) condemn our Play,
We thank you firſt; for here it was not writ
In ſweet repoſe and fluencies of wit;
But far remote, at Rome begun, half made
At Naples, at Paris the concluſion had.
Yet the perfection is behind, which (if
You give's a Plaudite) you in England give;
Our Nation's courteous unto ſtrangers, nor
Should you refrain unto this Traveller.
I muſt not ſue; Ther's nothing now remains,
Saving the Guerdon of our Poets pains:
He for himſelf is careleſs, onely wo'd,
That for the Actors ſakes you'd ſay 'tis good.
We are doubtful yet, your hands will ſet all right;
Do what you pleaſe, and (Gentlemen) Good night.
